commit_message:
Workaround Saucy trying to connect to DBUS

Devstack fails on saucy, because keystone-client calls end up trying to
connect to DBus. This connection fails due to the lack of DISPLAY
variable.

Workaround for bug #1242992

Change-Id: If6daae861128cab311c86beeaaa8fb1418760bf4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/83/86083/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ubuntu 13.10 # ------------ # See bug #1242992 # SecretService wants to connect to DBUS. if [[ ${DISTRO} =~ (saucy) ]]; then mkdir -p ~/.local/share/python_keyring/ cat > ~/.local/share/python_keyring/keyringrc.cfg << EOF [backend] default-keyring=keyring.backends.file.PlaintextKeyring EOF fi

commit_message:
Fix partial results sending in rps runner

Also made some improvements:
* removed class WorkerProcess
* properly calculated times_per_worker value
* properly calculated rps
* join threads once they finished

Change-Id: I15b604af6f5ec145e6a67265fba6c6443056137f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/07/110007/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SEND_RESULT_DELAY = 1 def worker_process(rps, times, queue, scenario_context, timeout, worker_id, cls, method_name, args): """Start scenario within threads. Spawn N threads per second. Each thread runs scenario once, and appends result to queue. :param rps: runs per second :param times: number of threads to be run :param queue: queue object to append results :param scenario_context: scenario context object :param timeout: timeout operation :param worker_id: id of worker process :param cls: scenario class :param method_name: scenario method name :param args: scenario args """ pool = [] def worker_thread(args): queue.put(base._run_scenario_once(args)) for i in range(times): scenario_args = (("%d:%d" % (worker_id, i), cls, method_name, scenario_context, args),) thread = threading.Thread(target=worker_thread, args=scenario_args) thread.start() pool.append(thread) time.sleep(1.0 / rps) while pool: thr = pool.pop() thr.join(timeout) processes2start = cpu_count if times >= cpu_count else times rps = processes2start / float(self.config["rps"]) times_per_worker, rest = divmod(times, processes2start) times = times_per_worker + int(rest > 0) rest -= 1 worker_args = (rps, times, queue, scenario_context, timeout, i, cls, method_name, args) process = multiprocessing.Process(target=worker_process, args=worker_args) while process_pool: for process in process_pool: process.join(SEND_RESULT_DELAY) if not process.is_alive(): process.join() while not queue.empty(): self._send_result(queue.get())
deleted_lines: rps = self.config["rps"] addition_args = args class WorkerProcess(multiprocessing.Process): def __init__(self, rps, times, queue, scenario_context, timeout, process_id, args): self.rps = rps self.times = times self.timeout = timeout self.pool = [] self.scenario_context = scenario_context self.id = process_id self.args = args self.queue = queue super(WorkerProcess, self).__init__() def _th_worker(self, args): result = base._run_scenario_once(args) self.queue.put(result) def run(self): for i in range(self.times): scenario_args = (("%d:%d" % (self.id, i), cls, method_name, self.scenario_context, self.args),) thread = threading.Thread(target=self._th_worker, args=scenario_args) thread.start() self.pool.append(thread) time.sleep(1.0 / rps) while len(self.pool): thr = self.pool.pop() thr.join(self.timeout) if times <= cpu_count: processes2start = times else: processes2start = cpu_count process = WorkerProcess(rps / float(processes2start), times / processes2start, queue, scenario_context, timeout, i, addition_args) while len(process_pool): for process in process_pool: if not process.is_alive(): process.join(timeout) if not queue.empty(): self._send_result(queue.get(timeout=timeout)) time.sleep(1.0 / rps) while not queue.empty(): result = queue.get(timeout=timeout) self._send_result(result)

commit_message:
Allow setup services endpoints

Adds setup_endpoints method which creates services endpoints including
service's user in keystone. It reflects behaviour of devtest
setup-endpoints script.

setup-endpoints command is included too. Endpoints configuration is
passed in JSON file or string.

Change-Id: Id57df4731502a99aee4405b72bdfd22e0d7eac64

oslo's set of default log levels with project specific ones.

Add keystonemiddleware as warn level since its verbose and nova isn't

Change-Id: I4b762eea922fe358ed2d0ac409b3caecced6ec96

commit_message:
Set keystonemiddleware and routes.middleware to log on WARN level

Thanks to I49a82c5b3446784d254ca558f51b6c3e5c2028eb, we can augment
oslo's set of default log levels with project specific ones.

Add keystonemiddleware as warn level since its verbose and nova isn't
trying to debug keystonemiddleware.

Add routes.middleware since this generates 3 log entries per API request
and doesn't help make debugging easier.

Change-Id: I4b762eea922fe358ed2d0ac409b3caecced6ec96
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/79/109379/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Except socket.error if syslog isn't running

When setting `use_syslog=true` and restarting the service, if syslog (or
rsyslog) isn't running, except the error and inform the user instead
of failing with a generic Errno 111.

Change-Id: Ie4ce3e84dcff838b569d6e2711aee5ea21c01083

commit_message:
Add glance.store to global requirements

Glance store is a new library responsible of managing the interaction
between glance and the stores backing it. This is required for:
Iaacc70993ad5da292b93de42bbecda73d53b19fd

Change-Id: Ic87bd483a30a79d41b186cd353964aea029894d0

commit_message:
log: make tests portable

There's no need to specify the address of the logger, and it actually
breaks the portability of the tests. With this patch, the tests also
work on Darwin.

Change-Id: Iae3fae1e089fd6ea03ac078a093f0c80a2988788

commit_message:
Add unicode coercion of logged messages to ContextFormatter

The ContextAdapter is being retired as part of
blueprint remove-context-adapter so any processing in the
ContextAdapter needs to be added to the ContextFormatter.

Coercion in the ContextAdapter was fixed as part
of change-id: I26b0d3490f731f6fdb9a429aa9ef59360ddc88ba

Partially implements blueprint remove-context-adapter

Change-Id: Icf4533074b45623983f4e3eeb7e1a1ae618bf605
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/35/112135/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_unicode_conversion_in_adapter(self): def test_unicode_conversion_in_formatter(self): ctxt = _fake_context() local.store.context = ctxt ctxt.request_id = six.text_type('99') try: no_adapt_log = logging.getLogger('no_adapt') no_adapt_log.setLevel(logging.INFO) message = "Exception is (%s)" ex = Exception(gettextutils.Message('test' + six.unichr(128))) no_adapt_log.info(message, ex) message = six.text_type(message) % ex expected = "HAS CONTEXT [%s]: %s\n" % (ctxt.request_id, message) self.assertEqual(expected, self.stream.getvalue()) finally: del local.store.context

commit_message:
Correct coercion of logged message to unicode

Changed to check if logged message is an instance of six.text_type
and coerce it to unicode if it isn't.

Change-Id: I26b0d3490f731f6fdb9a429aa9ef59360ddc88ba
Closes-bug: #1348244

commit_message:
Use oslotest by default

oslotest has been added to the requirements for new projects
created by oslo-cookiecutter, but the default test file still uses
a local copy of the base file.  Let's just use oslotest instead.

Also removes an unnecessary license header from the blank
__init__.py in the tests directory.

Change-Id: If96ae2d8fec05f6b0e86c08b0451567665ce80f4

commit_message:
Enhance versionutils.deprecated to work with classes

If object being decorated is a function, it is processed as before,
otherwise a new class is created which logs deprecated message when
class is instantiated. This change comes with 2 unit tests.

Closes-Bug: #1337889
Change-Id: Ib5cc04bea0ff2ea588618599f4e42df16cb85a0d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/16/104916/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: JUNO = 'J' 'J': 'Juno' def __call__(self, func_or_cls): if not self.what: self.what = func_or_cls.__name__ + '()' msg, details = self._build_message() if hasattr(func_or_cls, 'func_code'): @functools.wraps(func_or_cls) def wrapped(*args, **kwargs): LOG.deprecated(msg, details) return func_or_cls(*args, **kwargs) return wrapped else: class cls(func_or_cls): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): LOG.deprecated(msg, details) super(cls, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) return cls
deleted_lines: def __call__(self, func): if not self.what: self.what = func.__name__ + '()' @functools.wraps(func) def wrapped(*args, **kwargs): msg, details = self._build_message() LOG.deprecated(msg, details) return func(*args, **kwargs) return wrapped

commit_message:
Introduce a SemanticVersion object

This object represents a single semver version and provides serialisation
into different forms (dpkg/rpm/pep-440).

implements: blueprint pbr-semver
sem-ver: feature
Change-Id: I482e07cce9b65df452d5b9af4c73960df68a141e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/08/94108/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _is_int(string): try: int(string) return True except ValueError: return False class SemanticVersion(object): """A pure semantic version independent of serialisation. See the pbr doc 'semver' for details on the semantics. """ def __init__(self, major, minor=0, patch=0, prerelease_type=None, prerelease=None, dev_count=None, githash=None): """Create a SemanticVersion. :param major: Major component of the version. :param minor: Minor component of the version. Defaults to 0. :param patch: Patch level component. Defaults to 0. :param prerelease: What sort of prerelease version this is - one of a(alpha), b(beta) or rc(release candidate). :param prerelease: For prerelease versions, what number prerelease. Defaults to 0. :param dev_count: How many commits since the last release. :param githash: What tree hash is this version for. """ self._major = major self._minor = minor self._patch = patch self._prerelease_type = prerelease_type self._prerelease = prerelease if self._prerelease_type and not self._prerelease: self._prerelease = 0 self._dev_count = dev_count self._githash = githash def __eq__(self, other): if not isinstance(other, SemanticVersion): return False return self.__dict__ == other.__dict__ def __repr__(self): return "pbr.version.SemanticVersion(%s)" % self.release_string() @classmethod def from_pip_string(klass, version_string): """Create a SemanticVersion from a version string. This method will parse a version like 1.3.0 into a SemanticVersion. For compatibility 1.3.0a1 versions are handled, though SemanticVersion will output them as 1.3.0.0a1 for PEP-440 compatability. """ components = version_string.split('.') if len(components) < 3: components.extend([0] * (3 - len(components))) major = int(components[0]) minor = int(components[1]) dev_count = None prerelease_type = None prerelease = None githash = None def _parse_type(segment): prerelease_type = ''.join(s for s in segment[1:] if not s.isdigit()) prerelease = segment[1+len(prerelease_type)::] return prerelease_type, int(prerelease) if _is_int(components[2]): patch = int(components[2]) else: # legacy version e.g. 1.2.0a1 (canonical is 1.2.0.0a1) patch = 0 prerelease_type, prerelease = _parse_type(components[2]) remainder = components[3:] if not prerelease_type and remainder and remainder[0][0] == '0': # Current RC/beta layout prerelease_type, prerelease = _parse_type(remainder[0]) remainder = remainder[1:] if remainder: dev_count = int(remainder[0][3:]) + 1 if len(remainder) > 1: githash = remainder[1][1:] return SemanticVersion( major, minor, patch, prerelease_type=prerelease_type, prerelease=prerelease, dev_count=dev_count, githash=githash) def brief_string(self): """Return the short version minus any alpha/beta tags.""" return "%s.%s.%s" % (self._major, self._minor, self._patch) def debian_string(self): """Return the version number to use when building a debian package. This translates the PEP440/semver precedence rules into Debian version sorting operators. """ return self._long_version("~", "+g") def _long_version(self, pre_separator, hash_separator, rc_marker=""): """Construct a long string version of this semver. :param pre_separator: What separator to use between components that sort before rather than after. :param hash_separator: What separator to use to append the git hash. """ segments = [self.brief_string()] if self._prerelease_type: segments.append( "%s%s%s%s" % (pre_separator, rc_marker, self._prerelease_type, self._prerelease)) if self._dev_count: segments.append(pre_separator) if self._dev_count > 1: segments.append('dev') segments.append(self._dev_count - 1) if self._githash: segments.append(hash_separator) segments.append(self._githash) return "".join(str(s) for s in segments) def release_string(self): """Return the full version of the package. This including suffixes indicating VCS status. """ return self._long_version(".", ".g", "0") def version_tuple(self): """Present the version as a version_info tuple. For documentation on version_info tuples see the Python documentation for sys.version_info. Since semver and PEP-440 represent overlapping but not subsets of versions, we have to have some heuristic / mapping rules: - a/b/rc take precedence. - if there is no pre-release version the dev version is used. - serial is taken from the dev/a/b/c component. - final non-dev versions never get serials. """ segments = [self._major, self._minor, self._patch] if self._prerelease_type: type_map = {'a': 'alpha', 'b': 'beta', 'rc': 'candidate', } segments.append(type_map[self._prerelease_type]) segments.append(self._prerelease) elif self._dev_count: segments.append('dev') segments.append(self._dev_count) else: segments.append('final') segments.append(0) return tuple(segments) self._semantic = None result_string = provider.version result_string = packaging.get_version(self.package) return SemanticVersion.from_pip_string(result_string) return self.semantic_version().debian_string() return self.semantic_version().release_string() def semantic_version(self): """Return the SemanticVersion object for this version.""" if self._semantic is None: self._semantic = self._get_version_from_pkg_resources() return self._semantic return self.semantic_version().brief_string() return self.semantic_version().version_tuple()
deleted_lines: self.release = None return provider.version return packaging.get_version(self.package) def _is_int(self, string): try: int(string) return True except ValueError: return False segments = self.release_string().split('.') result_segments = [] for segment in segments: if not self._is_int(segment): if segment.startswith('g'): result_segments[-1] = result_segments[-1] + '+' else: result_segments[-1] = result_segments[-1] + '~' result_segments[-1] = result_segments[-1] + segment else: result_segments.append(segment) return ".".join(result_segments) if self.release is None: self.release = self._get_version_from_pkg_resources() return self.release if self.version is None: parts = [] for part in self.release_string().split('.'): if part[0].isdigit(): parts.append(part) else: break self.version = ".".join(parts) return self.version segments = self.release_string().split('.') if len(segments) < 3: segments.extend([0] * (3 - len(segments))) int_segments = tuple(int(s) for s in segments[:3]) if len(segments) == 3: return int_segments + ('final', 0) else: return int_segments + ('dev', int(segments[3][3:]))

commit_message:
Rename switch-to-mysql-connector spec

The approved spec doesn't mean "switching" to the new driver, but it
does mean enabling the new driver. Rename the spec and blueprint to
reflect that change in scope.

Change-Id: Ide7a01cc4a8294dec947ea4e9eb95a609c4a6109

commit_message:
Switch from MySQLdb to MySQL Connector

blueprint switch-to-mysql-connector

Change-Id: I679bc314a7933e410828f561fbf3dc82f031484b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/55/108355/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ====================================== Switch from MySQLdb to MySQL Connector ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/switch-to-mysql-connector Introduction paragraph -- why are we doing anything? Switch from MySQLdb to MySQL Connector which provides multiple benefits, including resilience of code and potential performance advantages. Problem description =================== The current MySQL client library we use (MySQLdb) plays badly with eventlet and may result in db deadlocks (see [#dead_locks]_). It also blocks execution of other green threads while we're deep in the library code (see [#one_thread]_). To avoid those issues, we need to switch to a pure python library with better eventlet support. MySQL Connector [#official_page]_ is an official MySQL Python client library and has the needed qualities. Proposed change =============== Oslo.db already supports using other MySQL drivers [#dialects]_. Oslo.db uses SQLAlchemy which supports switching client libraries by modifying the SQL connection URI that we pass to a service as a configuration option. So most work is around oslo.db, devstack, and documentation. (For details, see 'Work Items' section below.) Alternatives ------------ Some database lock timeouts can be mitigated by refactoring code [#hack_around_notifications]_. We may also introduce special mechanisms that would reduce the chances for the current thread to yield under transaction that are one of the main causes of db deadlocks. It is not realistic to expect that we're able to nail down and fix all occurances of possible yields under transactions. We could also switch to some other library that is also supported by SQLAlchemy [#dialects]_. Though those other libraries do not provide clear benefits in comparison to MySQL Connector, while the latter is the official driver for the MySQL project. We could also introduce a per-kernel-thread (or global) Python/eventlet lock around any calls into MySQLdb that may block. Not a particularly attractive option, because the impact on parallel operations is expected to be enormous. Finally, we could just drop eventlet from all our projects, though this option is not realistic. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Though MySQL Connector is a pure Python library, while MySQLdb is largely written in C, and we could expect that the new module is a bit slower than the current one, performance may actually be improved. This is because the new module is eventlet aware, meaning threads will be able to switch while waiting for I/O from a database server. This expectation is proved by the following measurements [#measurements]_. A simple performance test for Neutron was run locally on devstack to check impact of the change. Four scenarios were checked: * create 200 ports in serial * create 200 ports in parallel using 'futures' module with 10 thread workers * create 2000 networks in serial * create 2000 networks in parallel using 'futures' module with 10 thread workers Each scenario was run three times. For serial scenarios, the average result is pretty the same: * mysqldb (ports): 59.43 sec * mysql connector (ports): 62.81 sec * mysqldb (networks): 211.94 sec * mysql connector (networks): 206.80 sec For parallel scenarios, there is a very significant benefit: * mysqldb (ports): 58.37 sec * mysql connector (ports): 35.32 sec * mysqldb (networks): 215.81 sec * mysql connector (networks): 88.66 sec Configuration Impact -------------------- From configuration point of view, this is just a matter of changing connection string for each service. Old values should continue to work, so migration to the new library can be delayed or done iteratively. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ihar-hrachyshka Secondary assignee: gus (Angus Lees) Milestones ---------- Juno-3 Work Items ---------- The following items should be handled before claiming the switch to MySQL Connector to be completed: * oslo.db requires a few small changes for testing and feature parity with non-default MySQL drivers (development tracked by Angus Lees). * update devstack to use MySQL Connector instead of MySQLdb globally for all projects. * update installation guide to direct operators to install proper packages and set their configuration to use the new library. Incubation ========== None. Documentation Impact ==================== We should update the installation guide with new instructions on client library installation and setting proper 'connection' value for SQL connection URI. Dependencies ============ MySQL Connector should be posted to PyPI to be able to introduce it as part of global requirements list. References ========== .. [#dead_locks] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OpenStack_and_SQLAlchemy#MySQLdb_.2B_eventlet_.3D_sad .. [#one_thread] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/devref/threading.html .. [#official_page] http://www.mysql.com/products/connector/ .. [#dialects] http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/dialects/ .. [#hack_around_notifications] https://review.openstack.org/100934/ .. [#measurements] http://www.diamondtin.com/2014/sqlalchemy-gevent-mysql-python-drivers-comparison/ .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

subject: Use index-filter instead of tree-filter in graduate.sh
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-25 19:02:28.000000000', 'files': ['tools/graduate.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/cee1065bb7514e234322dec542efa2146f49d7ab', 'message': 'Use index-filter instead of tree-filter in graduate.sh

tree-filter causes git-filter-branch to checkout current tree for every
commit. That's rather IO-expensive operation. Given that tree-filter
runs "git rm" for every unneeded file, IO load becomes even higher.

With this change graduate.sh becomes less IO-bound and so runs way
faster (over 10x faster on my machine, even with tmpfs).

Change-Id: I3f08a3ac9a7f99a22b58c0c8017a53f4420fdcc3
'}]
commit_message:
Use index-filter instead of tree-filter in graduate.sh

tree-filter causes git-filter-branch to checkout current tree for every
commit. That's rather IO-expensive operation. Given that tree-filter
runs "git rm" for every unneeded file, IO load becomes even higher.

With this change graduate.sh becomes less IO-bound and so runs way
faster (over 10x faster on my machine, even with tmpfs).

Change-Id: I3f08a3ac9a7f99a22b58c0c8017a53f4420fdcc3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/85/109685/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # the prune script won't delete them from index. keep_pattern="\($(echo $files_to_keep | sed -e 's/ /\\|/g')\)" pruner="git ls-files | grep -v \"$keep_pattern\" | git update-index --force-remove --stdin; git ls-files > /dev/stderr"git filter-branch --index-filter "$pruner" --prune-empty HEAD
deleted_lines: # the prune script does not list them and cause them to be deleted. keep_pattern="./\(.git/\|$(echo $files_to_keep | sed -e 's/ /\\|/g')\)" pruner="$tmpdir/pruner.sh" cat >$pruner <<EOF #!/bin/bash find . -type f | grep -v "$keep_pattern" EOF chmod +x $prunergit filter-branch --tree-filter 'git rm -f $('$pruner')' --prune-empty HEAD

commit_message:
Documented Stevedore usage and source details

Updated architecture document to mention Stevedore
and make a correct statement about polling frequency.
Updated configuration document to reference the relevant
section of the architecture document.
Documented the name parameter of the source stanzas in pipeline.yaml.
Documented the behavior when multiple source stanzas match one plugin.

Change-Id: I0d09f2bd8943425cd250574df41e77a68bdcf55e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/07/111907/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Pollsters and Notification Plugins ================================== A pollster is a plugin that generates meter samples by periodically polling something. A notification plugin converts oslo notifications into meter samples. All the samples emitted by a given plugin should have the same meter name. Ceilometer uses Stevedore to load these plugins. The pollsters that will be loaded are declared in the ``[ceilometer.poll.central]`` section of the ``entry_points.txt`` file in the Ceilometer egg, and the notification plugins are declared in the ``[ceilometer.notification]`` section. Each plugin is declared by a line of the form:: entrypointname = module:Class where the entrypointname is identical to the meter name of the Samples emitted by the associated class. That restriction is not checked; if you violate it you will get no complaint but the consequent behavior is not documented. A pollster class must be a subclass of ``ceilometer.central.plugin:CentralPollster``. A pollster must have a generator method matching the signature .. code-block:: python def get_samples(self, manager, cache, resources=[]): This method should yield instances of ``ceilometer.sample:Sample``. A notification plugin's class must be a subclass of ``ceilometer.plugin:NotificationBase``. The *name* parameter of a source is unrelated to anything else; nothing references a source by name, and a source's name does not have to match anything. A given polling or notification plugin is invoked according to each source section whose *meters* parameter matches the plugin's meter name. That is, the matching source sections are combined by union, not intersection, of the prescribed time series.

commit_message:
NSX: unify the two distributed routing extensions

This is done by adopting the router_extra_attributes
models. However, the NSX 'distributed' extension is
slightly different in that it is visible to tenants
and prevents router conversion (allow_put=false).

PUT requests are made return the correct HTTP code;
The access control misalignments will need to be
adjusted via rules in policy.json. This will be
properly documented.

DocImpact

Supports-blueprint: neutron-ovs-dvr

Change-Id: I35a4b54318d8169eb2c73be77ca2f30bbee08b46

commit_message:
virtualbox scripts translates "\r" in VM basepath

Prevents interpretation of backslashes in output of functions
get_vm_base_path(), get_vms_running(), get_vms_present() in
functions/vm.sh.

Closes-bug: #1334070
Change-Id: I74986537e3afbae05b146d2c8c2e2262684d308e

commit_message:
Issue one SQL statement per execute() call

Some sqlalchemy drivers only support one SQL statement per execute()
call.  It isn't 100% clear from the sqlalchemy docs, but the sqlalchemy
author has confirmed that this is the intention.

Change-Id: I09d8a71c9157bbbe5930c423a1feb71740e384c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/46/113746/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: migrate_engine.execute("SET foreign_key_checks = 0") migrate_engine.execute( "ALTER TABLE %s ENGINE=InnoDB" % table) migrate_engine.execute( "ALTER TABLE %s CONVERT TO CHARACTER SET utf8" % table) migrate_engine.execute("SET foreign_key_checks = 1") migrate_engine.execute( "ALTER DATABASE %s DEFAULT CHARACTER SET utf8" % migrate_engine.url.database)
deleted_lines: sql = "SET foreign_key_checks = 0;" sql += "ALTER TABLE %s ENGINE=InnoDB;" % table sql += "ALTER TABLE %s CONVERT TO CHARACTER SET utf8;" % table sql += "SET foreign_key_checks = 1;" sql += "ALTER DATABASE %s DEFAULT CHARACTER SET utf8;" \ % migrate_engine.url.database migrate_engine.execute(sql)

commit_message:
Refactor common parts from cmd to wrapper

This is needed to allow daemon reuse these parts and be plugged in
clearly.

Change-Id: I01e020ae6f185faa446c715cf9a6b0c082260e13
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.rootwrap refs/changes/83/107083/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pwd import signal import subprocess def _subprocess_setup(): # Python installs a SIGPIPE handler by default. This is usually not what # non-Python subprocesses expect. signal.signal(signal.SIGPIPE, signal.SIG_DFL) def _getlogin(): try: return os.getlogin() except OSError: return (os.getenv('USER') or os.getenv('USERNAME') or os.getenv('LOGNAME')) def start_subprocess(filter_list, userargs, exec_dirs=[], log=False, **kwargs): filtermatch = match_filter(filter_list, userargs, exec_dirs) command = filtermatch.get_command(userargs, exec_dirs) if log: logging.info("(%s > %s) Executing %s (filter match = %s)" % ( _getlogin(), pwd.getpwuid(os.getuid())[0], command, filtermatch.name)) obj = subprocess.Popen(command, preexec_fn=_subprocess_setup, env=filtermatch.get_environment(userargs), **kwargs) return obj

commit_message:
Skip none value attributes for ec2 image bdm output.

Fix crash in _format_block_device_mapping when there are None values
for formatting attributes in the mapping.

Change-Id: I0ebdb844d75cdf1580cc88e1ff40fc21aff96f21
Closes-Bug: #1323403

commit_message:
Enhancing the make_test_data script

-Adding random boundaries rather than exact value for samples
-Allowing to pass datetime object or string
-Extracting make_test_data func, so it can be imported elsewhere
-Converting the integer time span to datetime

Change-Id: Iffbc8d9711b2f301a1f28b49980691ab34d17c20
Related-Bug: #1349791

commit_message:
Monitor Galera loss quorum condition

Pacemaker resource agent for Galera didn't detect 'Initialized' state.
This state happens when Galera lose quorum.

Change-Id: I3484e3c3c2d9c740d880ef73674b205c24402018
Closes-Bug: 1350545
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/64/113564/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif [[ "$WSREP_LOCAL_STATE_COMMENT" == 'Initialized' ]]; then ocf_log err 'MySQL lost quorum or uninitialized' return $OCF_ERR_GENERIC

commit_message:
Enable pc.ignore_quorum for Galera

- pc.ignore_quorum simplifies Galera quorum algorithm, allowing to
  loose 2/3 of 3 nodes.
- set O_DIRECT for innodb_flush

Change-Id: I1e4e3b11cfde6d768b9517bb5a564a9817059f39
Closes-Bug: 1350545
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/19/112019/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: innodb_flush_method=O_DIRECTwsrep_provider_options="pc.ignore_quorum=true"

commit_message:
Refactor benchmark/context/quota.py

Created new  directory context/quotas/
Moved to this directory quota.py module
Saperated NovaQuotas, CinderQuotas, NeutronQuotas
in separated files

Similar process done for tests refactoring

https://trello.com/c/ycDv6GD3

Change-Id: I322313d2817a071ab02a386b0fe0d397e3e3cdf0

commit_message:
Always replace orchestrator_data for deployment

- replace orchestrator_data for customized clusters

Change-Id: I590aae2937902e5c0bdc946493225d584470e3cb
Closes-Bug: 1354322
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/97/113297/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: orch_data = { "repo_metadata": { "nailgun": "http://10.20.0.2:8080/centos-5.0/centos/fuelweb/x86_64/" }, "puppet_modules_source": "rsync://10.20.0.2/puppet/release/5.0/modules", "puppet_manifests_source": "rsync://10.20.0.2/puppet/release/5.0/manifests" } "orchestrator_data": self.orch_data def test_orch_data_w_replaced_deployment_info(self): replaced_deployment_info = [{'repo_metadata': 'custom_stuff'}] release = self.env.create_release() self.env.create( cluster_kwargs={'release_id': release.id}, nodes_kwargs=[ {'roles': ['controller'], 'pending_addition': True} ]) objects.Release.update_orchestrator_data(release, self.orch_data) self.db.flush() self.db.refresh(release) self.env.nodes[0].replaced_deployment_info = replaced_deployment_info facts = self.serializer.serialize( self.env.clusters[0], self.env.nodes) self.assertEqual(facts[0]['repo_metadata'], self.orch_data['repo_metadata']) self.assertEqual(facts[0]['puppet_modules_source'], self.orch_data['puppet_modules_source']) self.assertEqual(facts[0]['puppet_manifests_source'], self.orch_data['puppet_manifests_source'])

subject: Fix docstring for scheduler_default_filters param
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-08 14:39:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/c1b1f4278c2ee22e0ff614fd3f5c081cc011edb1', 'message': "Fix docstring for scheduler_default_filters param

The docstring for the nova::scheduler::filter::scheduler_default_fitlers
paramater tells the user to specify it as a comma-separated string.
In actuality, the param is passed into stdlib's join() function, so
it's actually expecting an array.  This patch updates the documentation
accordingly.

Change-Id: Ib0b2757d4ddf0d9821aac8a1537e1338f69e1d69
Closes-bug: 1354477
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-08-08 14:42:16.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/scheduler/filter.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova/commit/3e3bfe77f53f89e74eb5a93cdeca17c2a2fa66f8', 'message': "Fix docstring for scheduler_default_filters param

The docstring for the nova::scheduler::filter::scheduler_default_filters
paramater tells the user to specify it as a comma-separated string.
In actuality, the param is passed into stdlib's join() function, so
it's actually expecting an array.  This patch updates the documentation
accordingly.

Change-Id: Ib0b2757d4ddf0d9821aac8a1537e1338f69e1d69
Closes-bug: 1354477
"}]
commit_message:
Fix docstring for scheduler_default_filters param

The docstring for the nova::scheduler::filter::scheduler_default_filters
paramater tells the user to specify it as a comma-separated string.
In actuality, the param is passed into stdlib's join() function, so
it's actually expecting an array.  This patch updates the documentation
accordingly.

Change-Id: Ib0b2757d4ddf0d9821aac8a1537e1338f69e1d69
Closes-bug: 1354477
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/97/112897/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (optional) An array of filters to be used by default
deleted_lines: # (optional) A comma separated list of filters to be used by default

Glance, swift use ClientPlugin.ignore_not_found

Change-Id: I24a7ebb10f2c9ff85cc2bdd6ce4a925c49b5ec3b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/24/100424/25 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default_client_name = 'swift' if self.resource_id is None: return try: self.swift().delete_container(self.resource_id) except Exception: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found() headers = self.swift().head_container(self.resource_id) if key == self.OBJECT_COUNT: return headers['x-container-object-count'] elif key == self.BYTES_USED: return headers['x-container-bytes-used'] elif key == self.HEAD_CONTAINER: return headers
deleted_lines: from heat.engine.clients.os import swift LOG.debug('SwiftContainer delete container %s' % self.resource_id) if self.resource_id is not None: try: self.swift().delete_container(self.resource_id) except swift.swiftclient.ClientException as ex: LOG.warn(_("Delete container failed: %s") % ex) try: headers = self.swift().head_container(self.resource_id) except swift.swiftclient.ClientException as ex: LOG.warn(_("Head container failed: %s") % ex) return None else: if key == self.OBJECT_COUNT: return headers['x-container-object-count'] elif key == self.BYTES_USED: return headers['x-container-bytes-used'] elif key == self.HEAD_CONTAINER: return headers if swift.swiftclient is None: return {}

commit_message:
Spec for stack lifecycle plugpoint

A cloud provider may have a need for custom code to examine stack requests
prior to performing the operations to create or update a stack.
Some providers may also need code to run after operations on
a stack complete. A mechanism is proposed whereby providers may easily add
pre-operation calls from heat to their own code, which is called prior to
performing the stack work, and post-operation calls, which are made after
a stack operation completes or fails.

blueprint stack-lifecycle-plugpoint

Change-Id: Ide4517f55267a1978ffffb264acd8a8128f38835
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/68/106468/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ============================= Stack lifecycle plugpoint ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/stack-lifecycle-plugpoint A cloud provider may have a need for custom code to examine stack requests prior to performing the operations to create or update a stack. Some providers may also need code to run after operations on a stack complete. A mechanism is proposed whereby providers may easily add pre-operation calls from heat to their own code, which is called prior to performing the stack work, and post-operation calls, which are made after a stack operation completes or fails. Problem description =================== There are at least two primary use cases. (1) Enabling holistic (whole-pattern) scheduling of the virtual resources in a template instance (stack) prior to creating or deleting them. This would usually include making decisions about where to host virtual resources in the physical infrastructure to satisfy policy requirements. It would also cover failing a stack create or update if the policies included with the stack create or update were not satisfiable, or other cloud provider policies being checked were not satisfiable. As an example, an application owner requires that VMs and volumes attached to them are deployed on the same rack. As another example, a cloud provider may want to enforce consultation with a license server before deploying an application. As another example, an application owner may require that their VMs be spread across a given number of racks. (2) Enabling checking of policies not related to virtual resource scheduling, with stack create or update failure if the policies would not be satisfied. As an example, a cloud provider may want to verify that compute resources for certain types of applications are deployed with certain security groups. As another example, a cloud provider may want to be warned when patterns with > 100 VMs are deployed. Proposed change =============== An ordered registry of python classes which implement pre-operation and/or post-operation methods is required. This could be done through the existing heat plugin loading mechanism that uses plugin_manager.py, with some addition to force a full (or partial) ordering on the classes, and eventually (2) through stevedore when/if heat switches to stevedore for resource plugin loading. Pre and post operation methods should not modify the parameter stack(s). Any modifications would be considered to be a bug. A possible exception would be to allow status changes to the stack, to facilitate error handling. [The no-modifications rule could be enforced, e.g. by passing deep copies to the plugins but this might incur an unacceptable performance cost.] Both pre-operation and post-operation methods can both indicate failure, which would be treated like any other stack failure. On failure of a pre-operation call, when more than one plugin is registered, the post-op methods would be called for all the classes already processed, to indicate to each plugin that any decisions that it made with respect to the stack should be un-made. All stack actions would need calls to either pre or post operations, or both. This includes at least create, update, delete, abandon, and adopt. In a basic design, modifications to the Stack class in parser.py are sufficient for adding the call to the pre-operation and post-operation methods found via the lifecycle plugin registry. The post-operation calls would need to be called in both the normal paths and all error paths. The changes would reside in * heat/common * heat/engine * heat/engine/resources * heat/tests Alternatives ------------ No other approach was identified that would allow the operator (heat provider) to extend heat with this functionality for all stack deployments. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/lifecycle-callbacks describes an approach where heat users can optionally specify callbacks for in templates for stack and resource events. It does not provide the ubiquitous callbacks (for all stacks) that would be needed by the use cases described above, unless the heat provider tightly controls the templates that users can use. Implementation ============== A patch comprising a full implementation of the blueprint (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/89363/) is already being reviewed, under the old pre-spec process. Primary assignee: William C. Arnold (barnold-8) Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Juno-2 Work Items ---------- Implementation: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/89363/ Dependencies ============ No dependencies

added_lines: TMPDIR=$(mktemp -d) export BUILD_SEED_RAMDISK=$TMPDIR/build_seed_RAMDISK.lock export BOOT_SEED=$TMPDIR/boot_seed.lock export BOOT_CLOUD=$TMPDIR/boot_cloud.lock export BUILD_CLOUD=$TMPDIR/build_cloud.lock (flock -s $BUILD_SEED_RAMDISK -c "echo 'SEED: building...'; devtest_seed.sh --build-only 1>/dev/null 2>&1 && echo 'SEED: build OK' || echo 'SEED: build FAILED'") (flock -s $BUILD_SEED_RAMDISK -c "echo 'RAMDISK: building...'; devtest_seed.sh --build-only 1>/dev/null 2>&1 && echo 'RAMDISK: build OK' || echo 'RAMDISK: build FAILED'") sleep 1 boot_seed(){ echo 'SEED: booting...'; USE_CACHE=1 devtest_seed.sh 1>$TRIPLEO_ROOT/seed_boot.log 2>&1 && echo 'SEED: boot OK' || echo 'SEED: boot FAILED' } boot_undercloud(){ flock -s $BOOT_SEED -c "echo 'UNDERCLOUD: booting...'; USE_CACHE=1 devtest_undercloud.sh $TE_DATAFILE 1>$TRIPLEO_ROOT/undercloud_boot.log 2>&1 && echo 'UNDERCLOUD: boot OK' || echo 'UNDERCLOUD: boot FAILED'" } build_undercloud(){ echo 'UNDERCLOUD: building...'; devtest_undercloud.sh $TE_DATAFILE --build-only 1>/dev/null 2>&1 && echo 'UNDERCLOUD: build OK' || echo 'UNDERCLOUD: build FAILED' } boot_overcloud(){ flock -s $BOOT_SEED -c " echo 'OVERCLOUD: booting...'; source $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-incubator/seedrc && setup-baremetal --service-host seed --nodes <(jq '.nodes - [.nodes[0]]' $TE_DATAFILE) && USE_CACHE=1 devtest_overcloud.sh 1>$TRIPLEO_ROOT/overcloud_boot.log 2>&1 && echo 'OVERCLOUD: boot OK' || echo 'OVERCLOUD: boot FAILED'" } build_overcloud(){ echo 'OVERCLOUD: building...'; devtest_overcloud.sh --build-only 1>/dev/null 2>&1 && echo 'OVERCLOUD: build OK' || echo -e 'OVERCLOUD: build FAILED' } export -f boot_undercloud export -f build_overcloud export -f boot_overcloud export -f boot_seed export -f build_undercloud (flock -x $BOOT_SEED -c 'flock -s $BUILD_SEED_RAMDISK -c boot_seed') sleep 1 (flock -x $BUILD_CLOUD -c 'flock -s $BUILD_SEED_RAMDISK -c build_undercloud')& sleep 1 (flock -x $BOOT_CLOUD -c 'flock -s $BUILD_CLOUD -c boot_undercloud')& (flock -x $BUILD_CLOUD -c 'flock -s $BUILD_SEED_RAMDISK -c build_overcloud' )& sleep 1 (flock -x $BOOT_CLOUD -c 'flock -s $BUILD_CLOUD -c boot_overcloud')&sleep 1 flock -x $BOOT_CLOUD -c "echo 'Run completed.'"

added_lines: class TogglePublicEnabled(tables.BatchAction): name = 'toggle_public_enabled' data_type_singular = _('Public') data_type_plural = _('Public') action_present = _('Toggle') action_past = _('Toggled') def handle(self, table, request, obj_ids): for obj_id in obj_ids: try: api.muranoclient(request).packages.toggle_public(obj_id) except exc.HTTPException: LOG.exception(_('Toggling package public state in package ' 'repository failed')) exceptions.handle(request, _('Unable to toggle package public state.')) else: obj = table.get_object_by_id(obj_id) obj.is_public = not obj.is_public messages.success( request, _("Public state for package '{0}' is successfully toggled") .format(obj.name)) is_public = tables.Column('is_public', verbose_name=_('Public')) TogglePublicEnabled, TogglePublicEnabled,

ATTENTION: this solution conflicts with
https://review.openstack.org/112077

- Use SIGTERM instead of SIGINT for dhcrelay_monitor supervisor
  service, because we have "sleep 30" loop in the monitor script,
  so it will handle SIGINT only when sleep ends.
- Send KILL instead of INT to "dockerctl attach" process to make
  sure we don't stop any container during supervisor shutdown or
  restart. This should make supervisor restart much faster and
  it's safe for upgrade process since we're not shutting down any
  containers. Supervisor only monitors them and brings them up,
  but does not stop them.

Change-Id: I08b50cf6f6ca7a93f446d07096ad25909ff60893
Related-bug: #1350764
(cherry picked from commit e3c30e50a99e143afcc705e258b9899a4151b9ff)

commit_message:
Don't stop docker containers from supervisor

ATTENTION: this solution conflicts with
https://review.openstack.org/112077

- Use SIGTERM instead of SIGINT for dhcrelay_monitor supervisor
  service, because we have "sleep 30" loop in the monitor script,
  so it will handle SIGINT only when sleep ends.
- Send KILL instead of INT to "dockerctl attach" process to make
  sure we don't stop any container during supervisor shutdown or
  restart. This should make supervisor restart much faster and
  it's safe for upgrade process since we're not shutting down any
  containers. Supervisor only monitors them and brings them up,
  but does not stop them.

Change-Id: I08b50cf6f6ca7a93f446d07096ad25909ff60893
Related-bug: #1350764
(cherry picked from commit e3c30e50a99e143afcc705e258b9899a4151b9ff)

commit_message:
Change overcloud to use VIP for MySQL

This change sets applications to utilize the VIP address for database
connectivity and sets HAProxy in between the applications and MySQL.

Depends upon tripleo-image-elements changes:
    Ia6f26305f8e744e4ff938dff85de1193183ecd8f
    Iac1274cc52014f25887d696261b32146afc926dd
    I5af70abb96021146c098f788db349808d806a348

Related to blueprint tripleo-icehouse-ha-production-configuration

subject: Rename the "Identity" program
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-22 15:47:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/c3e3c654a72740b9d19cce192bfdf7eb3d6e29d8', 'message': 'Rename the "Identity" program to "TripleA"

TripleA refers to the combination of:

    Authentication + Authorization + Auditing

This name change is becoming more appropriate as the following trends
continue to develop:

1. Auditing becomes increasingly important to OpenStack operators.

2. Keystone works to further leverage external identity providers,
   making keystone itself a second class Identity provider.

In choosing a name/spelling, I followed the lead of TripleO's camel
casing, instead of using alternatives such as Triple-A or AAA.

This change also moves the PyCADF library to the TripleA program, which
provides OpenStack's auditing data model.

Change-Id: Ic911fdb11c79d55a5a9ef62c950c6eaa232c630c
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-07-23 15:37:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/031f53afdb6eb7c99c4fbf7034697fb8dd36dbb6', 'message': 'Rename the "Identity" program

commit_message:
Rename the "Identity" program

This name change is becoming more appropriate as the following trends
continue to develop:

1. Auditing becomes increasingly important to OpenStack operators and
   the program's mission.

2. Keystone works to further leverage external identity providers,
   making keystone itself a second class Identity provider.

Change-Id: Ic911fdb11c79d55a5a9ef62c950c6eaa232c630c

commit_message:
Move integration tests under mistralclient/tests folder

- Collect all tests in one folder 'mistralclient/tests'.
- Create new folder 'functional' in the mistralclient/tests for integration functional tests.
- Restructure tests, create folder 'v1' for current tests (version 1).
- Create new folder 'unit' in the mistralclient/tests and put all unit tests here.
- Correct imports in the file with unit tests.

Change-Id: If92c11640d7cb61ee8ffcdc7ba99d7ab1061afa7

commit_message:
Change Volume metadata attribute to raw dict.

Currently the volume metadata attribute is json
serialized, but outputting the raw dict is more
convenient for human users. This is fixed by
introducing a new attribute 'metadata_values'
whose output is in raw dict form. The attribte
'metadata' is preserved for those users who are
already used to its json serialized output.

Change-Id: Ib95656fa8632449957cd8c24b232f4d1b09a0e42
Closes-Bug: #1322007

commit_message:
Remove deprecated commands from shell

Remove all deprecated commands from the shell
since they are no longer used and to keep
the command line menu from looking cluttered.

Closes-bug: #1314218

Change-Id: I66e82872988e3835e4f290f48dfc80538271426c

commit_message:
Remove "--disabled" for firewall create rule

Allow "--enabled True/False" and remove "--disabled" for consistency across
all commands. Even in other neutron commands, we are using only --enabled
option but not --disabled. firewall-rule-show displays only "enabled" attribute
and there is no "disabled" attribute.

Change-Id: Ie591d827660466a774e431dcb40e04e09773e5f7
Closes-bug: 1327056

subject: Allow form to stay modal after uploading file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-17 16:29:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/7b3e78ce2fa3b14b53e1fd654bcc272f7c84810c', 'message': 'Enable file upload field in modal forms

It works only for one file input, still improving...

Change-Id: Id3b91a49a71c6de314c6a7cbee5357fe13679490
Closes-Bug: #1158501
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-07-21 15:15:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/34592fa81ffdaa7412b0eb8ab2fcf05d0b991235', 'message': 'Allow form to stay modal after uploading file

Use JQuery Form Plugin for this purpose (placed in
horizon/static/horizon/lib/jquery). Browsers without XHR file upload
support (most importantly, IE<10) do not support setting custom AJAX
request headers, so form with File Upload field still loses modality
in them.

Change-Id: Id3b91a49a71c6de314c6a7cbee5357fe13679490
Closes-Bug: #1158501
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-07-22 14:06:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/b92f1bf8290526306bfa8d24432277074b2ab298', 'message': 'Allow form to stay modal after uploading file

Use HTML5 FormData browser API together with FileList API to make
possible AJAX file uploads (see http://tinyurl.com/kmznw2n on FormData
examples). Feature detection is the same as in jQuery Form Plugin (see
http://tinyurl.com/n6v5dsx). Browsers without FormData support (most
importantly, IE<10) do not support setting custom AJAX request
headers, so form with File Upload field will lose modality in them
anyway.

Change-Id: Id3b91a49a71c6de314c6a7cbee5357fe13679490
Closes-Bug: #1158501

commit_message:
Allow form to stay modal after uploading file

Use HTML5 FormData browser API together with FileList API to make
possible AJAX file uploads (see http://tinyurl.com/kmznw2n on FormData
examples). Feature detection is the same as in jQuery Form Plugin (see
http://tinyurl.com/n6v5dsx). Browsers without FormData support (most
importantly, IE<10) do not support setting custom AJAX request
headers, so form with File Upload field will lose modality in them
anyway.

Change-Id: Id3b91a49a71c6de314c6a7cbee5357fe13679490
Closes-Bug: #1158501

'&' : '?'; // XDomainRequest only supports GET and POST: if (options.type === 'DELETE') { options.url = options.url + addParamChar + '_method=DELETE'; options.type = 'POST'; } else if (options.type === 'PUT') { options.url = options.url + addParamChar + '_method=PUT'; options.type = 'POST'; } else if (options.type === 'PATCH') { options.url = options.url + addParamChar + '_method=PATCH'; options.type = 'POST'; } // IE versions below IE8 cannot set the name property of // elements that have already been added to the DOM, // so we set the name along with the iframe HTML markup: counter += 1; iframe = $( '<iframe src="' + initialIframeSrc + '" name="iframe-transport-' + counter + '"></iframe>' ).bind('load', function () { var fileInputClones, paramNames = $.isArray(options.paramName) ? options.paramName : [options.paramName]; iframe .unbind('load') .bind('load', function () { var response; // Wrap in a try/catch block to catch exceptions thrown // when trying to access cross-domain iframe contents: try { response = iframe.contents(); // Google Chrome and Firefox do not throw an // exception when calling iframe.contents() on // cross-domain requests, so we unify the response: if (!response.length || !response[0].firstChild) { throw new Error(); } } catch (e) { response = undefined; } // The complete callback returns the // iframe content document as response object: completeCallback( 200, 'success', {'iframe': response} ); // Fix for IE endless progress bar activity bug // (happens on form submits to iframe targets): $('<iframe src="' + initialIframeSrc + '"></iframe>') .appendTo(form); window.setTimeout(function () { // Removing the form in a setTimeout call // allows Chrome's developer tools to display // the response result form.remove(); }, 0); }); form .prop('target', iframe.prop('name')) .prop('action', options.url) .prop('method', options.type); if (options.formData) { $.each(options.formData, function (index, field) { $('<input type="hidden"/>') .prop('name', field.name) .val(field.value) .appendTo(form); }); } if (options.fileInput && options.fileInput.length && options.type === 'POST') { fileInputClones = options.fileInput.clone(); // Insert a clone for each file input field: options.fileInput.after(function (index) { return fileInputClones[index]; }); if (options.paramName) { options.fileInput.each(function (index) { $(this).prop( 'name', paramNames[index] || options.paramName ); }); } // Appending the file input fields to the hidden form // removes them from their original location: form .append(options.fileInput) .prop('enctype', 'multipart/form-data') // enctype must be set as encoding for IE: .prop('encoding', 'multipart/form-data'); // Remove the HTML5 form attribute from the input(s): options.fileInput.removeAttr('form'); } form.submit(); // Insert the file input fields at their original location // by replacing the clones with the originals: if (fileInputClones && fileInputClones.length) { options.fileInput.each(function (index, input) { var clone = $(fileInputClones[index]); // Restore the original name and form properties: $(input) .prop('name', clone.prop('name')) .attr('form', clone.attr('form')); clone.replaceWith(input); }); } }); form.append(iframe).appendTo(document.body); }, abort: function () { if (iframe) { // javascript:false as iframe src aborts the request // and prevents warning popups on HTTPS in IE6. // concat is used to avoid the "Script URL" JSLint error: iframe .unbind('load') .prop('src', initialIframeSrc); } if (form) { form.remove(); } } }; } }); // The iframe transport returns the iframe content document as response. // The following adds converters from iframe to text, json, html, xml // and script. // Please note that the Content-Type for JSON responses has to be text/plain // or text/html, if the browser doesn't include application/json in the // Accept header, else IE will show a download dialog. // The Content-Type for XML responses on the other hand has to be always // application/xml or text/xml, so IE properly parses the XML response. // See also // https://github.com/blueimp/jQuery-File-Upload/wiki/Setup#content-type-negotiation $.ajaxSetup({ converters: { 'iframe text': function (iframe) { return iframe && $(iframe[0].body).text(); }, 'iframe json': function (iframe) { return iframe && $.parseJSON($(iframe[0].body).text()); }, 'iframe html': function (iframe) { return iframe && $(iframe[0].body).html(); }, 'iframe xml': function (iframe) { var xmlDoc = iframe && iframe[0]; commit_message:
Fix dict format in wait_condition.py docstrings

As mentioned in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102888/19
there are a couple of mistakes in the docstrings, which were
unfortunately not addressed before merging, so fix now.

Change-Id: I8fbc34882b6476b75c950b16243aac43ad2a97fb

commit_message:
Carrys the proxy variable while installing trove-integration

    Closes-Bug: 1322200

    Carrys the proxy variable (http_proxy/https_proxy/no_proxy) to sudo,
    while installing trove-integration. Fixing the Bug 1322200

Change-Id: I811586fb55919744fb87a1e735a6091a0142c91c

commit_message:
WIP: Port v2 volumes extension into v2.1

This patch port v2 volumes extension into v2.1, and try to share
volume attachment code between v2.1 and v3.

* move volumes and assisted volume snapshots into v2.1
* add block device mapping for v2.1
* translate block device mapping v2 for v2.1
* port the unittest

* TODO: input validation
* TODO: shared inittests with v2
* TODO: Find a way extend the translation mapping for
block_device_mapping_v2

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I88c3fa729b0b74f32313fd546c30389ce2c1d3e2

added_lines: # TODO(alex xu): Find a way to extend this translation mapping 'block_device_mapping_v2': { 'rename_to': 'os-block-device-mapping:block_device_mapping' }

subject: WIP: Distinguish different behavior between v2.1 and v3
revisions:
[{'number': 14, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9fd556b93b6c29c76470432144d65632eee47574', 'message': 'WIP: Distinguish different behavior between v2.1 and v3

This patch add a decorator to distinguish different version for same name
function. When invoke this kind of multiversion function, it will depend
on the api request version to decide which version of function will be invoked.

PoC target
 * get servers on the specified hypervisor:
    diff: Change API URL
             - '/os-hypervisors/[filters]/servers'
             + '/os-hypervisors/[hypervisor id]/servers'
          Rename attributes of response (uuid -> id)
    v3 patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33775/4

 * search hypervisor on the specified hypervisor"
    diff: Change API URL
             - '/os-hypervisors/[filters]/search'
             + '/os-hypervisors/search?query=[filters]'
          Rename attributes of response (uuid -> id)
    v3 patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33774/

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I44c208091004e88299d71820a389effe203709de

commit_message:
WIP: Distinguish different behavior between v2.1 and v3

This patch add a decorator to distinguish different version for same name
function. When invoke this kind of multiversion function, it will depend
on the api request version to decide which version of function will be invoked.

PoC target
 * get servers on the specified hypervisor:
    diff: Change API URL
             - '/os-hypervisors/[filters]/servers'
             + '/os-hypervisors/[hypervisor id]/servers'
          Rename attributes of response (uuid -> id)
    v3 patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33775/4

 * search hypervisor on the specified hypervisor"
    diff: Change API URL
             - '/os-hypervisors/[filters]/search'
             + '/os-hypervisors/search?query=[filters]'
          Rename attributes of response (uuid -> id)
    v3 patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33774/

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I44c208091004e88299d71820a389effe203709de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/01/82301/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class FakeController(wsgi.Controller): @wsgi.Controller.version('2.1') def fake_func(self, req): return 1 @wsgi.Controller.version('3.0') def fake_func(self, req): return 2 def normal_func(self, req): return 3 class ControllerTest(test.NoDBTestCase): def test_call_multi_version_function(self): controller = FakeController() req = wsgi.Request.blank('/tests/123', method='POST', base_url='http://localhost/v2.1') self.assertEqual(controller.fake_func(req), 1) req = wsgi.Request.blank('/tests/123', method='POST', base_url='http://localhost/v3') self.assertEqual(controller.fake_func(req), 2) def test_call_normal_function(self): controller = FakeController() req = wsgi.Request.blank('/tests/123', method='POST', base_url='http://localhost/v3') self.assertEqual(controller.normal_func(req), 3)

subject: WIP Register different action and resource name for v2.1 on v3
revisions:
[{'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/779642e864e4f16cf0c077c6778368b9744d6928', 'message': "WIP register different action and resource name for v2.1 on v3

This patch use decorator or arguments on v3 code to register
different action and resource name for v2.1.

PoC Item:
resource name change: keypair -> os-keypair
action name change: migrate_live -> os_migrateLive

This is PoC patch.

Another approach is https://review.openstack.org/#/c/78906/ ,
That approach can handle more complex cases. It also provide
separated namespace for v2.1. It's easy to fake v2 extension structure.
For example, In v3 AdminActions extensions was split as multiple extensions,
It's easy to fake an v2's AdminActions on v3. The benefit is if the admin
want to disable AdminActions, admin only need specfic it in the extension
black list. And api user can query whether AdminActions is enabled by api.
But there is concern on the overhead.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I8476885e6892632e2fdc4af6923d2d3f25aa1713

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e8ee95c8718e7fe7d349666be10a49d11678f04e', 'message': 'WIP Register different action and resource name for v2.1 on v3

This patch adds an APIRouterV21 class and the api-paste code
required to implement a /v2.1/ REST API resource.

This patch uses a decorator to implement a different action
name for migrate live for V2.1 (keeping with V2) compared to
the V3 API.

The infrastructure is also added to supply an optional version
number to the Keypairs plugin get_resources method which allows
it to return a different resource name for V2.1 compared to V3.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I8476885e6892632e2fdc4af6923d2d3f25aa1713

commit_message:
WIP Register different action and resource name for v2.1 on v3

This patch adds an APIRouterV21 class and the api-paste code
required to implement a /v2.1/ REST API resource.

This patch uses a decorator to implement a different action
name for migrate live for V2.1 (keeping with V2) compared to
the V3 API.

The infrastructure is also added to supply an optional version
number to the Keypairs plugin get_resources method which allows
it to return a different resource name for V2.1 compared to V3.

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I8476885e6892632e2fdc4af6923d2d3f25aa1713
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/98/80198/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: supported_versions = ['2.1'] def get_resources(self, version=''): if version == '2.1': resources = [extensions.ResourceExtension('os-keypairs', KeypairController())] else: resources = [extensions.ResourceExtension('keypairs', KeypairController())]

commit_message:
Network: do not pass unnecessary parameters

Commit 6d12d70a42b922225dd16338ec9db8c60df89e38 passed parameters
that were the default ones. These have been removed.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I9bc4020ce0a6416dc74e1f2d520d573eba6a3fd6

commit_message:
Make Murano stats panel visible to admin only

In the absence of RBAC implementation, make the stats panel accessible
only to users with role 'admin', as with other horizon components.

Change-Id: I5231e682796d83625c4fbde294c7ad2289e1e55d
Implements: blueprint stats-panel-visible-to-admin-only
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/32/113032/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: permissions = ('openstack.roles.admin',)

commit_message:
Add stack-check action to the API

Add CHECK to the list of accepted stack actions.

Co-Authored-By: Richard Lee <rblee88@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint stack-check (partial)
Change-Id: I38265b672090f5fcc34413cc4d8c086015af869c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/05/89905/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @property def ignore_template(self): return (self.update_type() in engine_api.STACK_UPDATE_TYPES) if self.ignore_template: return {} def update_type(self): update_type = self.data.get(engine_api.PARAM_UPDATE_TYPE) or None if update_type in engine_api.STACK_UPDATE_TYPES: return update_type

Allow resource to check whether it is in an expected state and update
status and action accordingly.

This adds a check action to the stack that will perform checks in all
their resources and nested resources as well.  If a resource doesn't
have a handle_check() method, check for that resource will just pass.

If any resource at the end of a Stack.check() doesn't have a
handle_check() method, then a message will be added to the status_reason
of both the resource and the stack saying that CHECK is not (fully)
supported.  This allows for the other resources to implement their own
checks for their expected states.

Co-Authored-By: Richard Lee <rblee88@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint stack-check (partial)
Change-Id: I18985476696faeaa47149c233a067f9494c2effa

commit_message:
Check resources are in expected states

Allow resource to check whether it is in an expected state and update
status and action accordingly.

This adds a check action to the stack that will perform checks in all
their resources and nested resources as well.  If a resource doesn't
have a handle_check() method, check for that resource will just pass.

If any resource at the end of a Stack.check() doesn't have a
handle_check() method, then a message will be added to the status_reason
of both the resource and the stack saying that CHECK is not (fully)
supported.  This allows for the other resources to implement their own
checks for their expected states.

Co-Authored-By: Richard Lee <rblee88@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint stack-check (partial)
Change-Id: I18985476696faeaa47149c233a067f9494c2effa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/08/89908/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_check_marks_a_successful_check_as_complete(self): tmpl = {'Type': 'foo'} res = generic_rsrc.ResourceWithProps('test_resource', tmpl, self.stack) res.handle_check = mock.Mock(return_value=True) scheduler.TaskRunner(res.check)() self.assertEqual((res.UPDATE, res.COMPLETE), res.state) def test_check_marks_the_resource_as_failed_when_exception_is_raised(self): tmpl = {'Type': 'foo'} res = generic_rsrc.ResourceWithProps('test_resource', tmpl, self.stack) ex = Exception('fail') res.handle_check = mock.Mock(side_effect=ex) self.assertRaises(exception.ResourceFailure, scheduler.TaskRunner(res.check)) self.assertEqual((res.UPDATE, res.FAILED), res.state) def test_marks_the_resource_as_in_progress_while_updating(self): tmpl = {'Type': 'foo'} res = generic_rsrc.ResourceWithProps('test_resource', tmpl, self.stack) res.handle_check = mock.Mock(return_value=True) res.state_set = mock.Mock() scheduler.TaskRunner(res.check)() mock_state_set_in_progress = mock.call(res.UPDATE, res.IN_PROGRESS) self.assertIn(mock_state_set_in_progress, res.state_set.call_args_list) def test_handle_check_default_implementation_raises_not_supported(self): tmpl = {'Type': 'foo'} res = generic_rsrc.ResourceWithProps('test_resource', tmpl, self.stack) self.assertRaises(exception.NotSupported, res.handle_check)

commit_message:
Optimize get_by_instance_uuid

Previously this method was issuing two requests: One filtering the node
by instance_uuid and another to get all the informations about that
node. This patch optimize it by using the /detail flag which will filter
the node by the instance_uuid and return all informations in one request.

Change-Id: Ia22c5012af12b131d5a6601653d704b5a9f39d82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/69/113469/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add __future__ import to register-nodes

register-nodes makes use of print, which means we should be explicit
and import print_function from __future__. This also makes futurize
happy with os-cloud-config.

Change-Id: I14523779a1f207fa389ddb59073cc9bfdda89386
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-cloud-config refs/changes/36/111536/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from __future__ import print_function

commit_message:
HOT guide structure

This patch provides a structure for the HOT guide, without content. The
intent is to provide an overview of what needs to be documented.

The organization will probably change once we turn this book into a
chapter in the user guide.

Change-Id: I640c519e2c0d1f1b6ba974f37aa4cb2abcfd59c1
Implements: blueprint heat-templates

commit_message:
Fix manager.status_timeout exception

Method should not raise BuildErrorException, unless called specifically after
VM is created, to verify 'ACTIVE' state

Change-Id: I905ca17eeb9ec3767d1c1fb2ccc005b7c4d66c3b
Closes-Bug: #1335754
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/47/103547/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.wait_for_volume(volume, 'available') self.wait_for_volume_snapshot(snapshot, 'available') self.wait_for_volume(attached_volume, 'in-use') self.wait_for_volume(volume, 'available')
deleted_lines: def _wait_for_volume_snapshot_status(self, volume_snapshot, status): self.status_timeout(self.volume_client.volume_snapshots, volume_snapshot.id, status) self._wait_for_volume_status(volume, 'available') self._wait_for_volume_snapshot_status(snapshot, 'available') def _wait_for_volume_status(self, volume, status): self.status_timeout( self.volume_client.volumes, volume.id, status) self._wait_for_volume_status(attached_volume, 'in-use') self._wait_for_volume_status(volume, 'available')
