commit_message:
Support emulation v2 extension output with v3 framework

Adds a v2.1 mode to the v3 extensions plugin. There is not a 1-1
mapping of extensions (or core) between the V2 and V3 API so a
manual lookup table is required to translate between V3 and what
should be presented as the V2 API

TODO: The table is incomplete - this is just a POC.
TODO: Core parts of the V3 API are still published into the V2
  extensions list. This will eventually be removed from the V3 API
  as well anyway

Partially implements blueprint v2-on-v3-api

Change-Id: I877394a1a54cd2540da1e87856493e5b8b3d6023

added_lines: from nova.api.openstack import wsgiclass ExtensionInfoController(wsgi.Controller): @wsgi.Controller.version('3.0') def _translate(self, req, alias, ext): @wsgi.Controller.version('2.1') def _translate(self, req, alias, ext): # Map to updated extension info with # keypairs is an example of a simple renaming of the alias # os-scheduler-hints is an example of keeping the updated and # namespace fields if we really need them # os-quota-sets is an example of mapping on v3 extension # and display multiple v2 extensions v2_ext_info = { 'os-keypairs': {'alias': 'os-keypairs'}, 'OS-SCH-HNT': {'alias': 'OS-SCH-HNT', 'updated': '2011-07-19T00:00:00+00:00', 'namespace': ("http://docs.openstack.org/" "compute/ext/scheduler-hints/" "api/v2")}, 'os-quota-sets': {}, 'os-extended-quotas': {'alias': 'os-extended-quotas'} } ext_data = {} override_info = v2_ext_info.get(alias, {}) ext_data['name'] = override_info.get('name', ext.name) ext_data['alias'] = override_info.get('alias', ext.alias) ext_data['description'] = override_info.get('description', ext.__doc__) ext_data['namespace'] = override_info.get('namespace', "DUMMY_NAMESPACE") # TODO(cyeoh): won't need to about a valid namespace if XML support # for the V2 API is removed in Juno. Otherwise every extension # will need an entry for this. ext_data['updated'] = "2014-03-31T00:00:00+00:00" # NOTE: Does anyone actually use this field? ext_data['links'] = [] # links is always an empty list return ext_data def _get_discoverable_extensions(self, context): @wsgi.Controller.version('3.0') def _get_extensions(self, req, context): return self._get_discoverable_extensions(context) @wsgi.Controller.version('2.1') def _get_extensions(self, req, context): # Need filter out some extensions which don't exist in V2 # but the functionality does, and also create entries for # extensions which no longer exist in V3 as the feature # has been merged into another extensions # keypairs and os-scheduler-hints are examples of alias name # mapping # os-quota-sets is an example of mapping one V3 extension to # multiple V2 extensions # os-access-ips is an example of a V3 extension which does not # exist in V2 because it was part of core v3_to_v2_ext_map = { 'keypairs': ['os-keypairs'], # Simple name mapping 'os-scheduler-hints': ['OS-SCH-HNT'], # Simple name mapping 'os-quota-sets': ['os-quota-sets', 'os-extended-quotas'], 'os-access-ips': [] } discovered_exts = self._get_discoverable_extensions( context).iteritems() exts = dict() for alias, ext in discovered_exts: if alias in v3_to_v2_ext_map: for v2_ext_name in v3_to_v2_ext_map[alias]: exts[v2_ext_name] = ext else: exts[alias] = ext return exts self._get_extensions(req, context).iteritems()) for alias, ext in sorted_ext_list: extensions.append(self._translate(req, alias, ext)) ext = self._get_extensions(req, context)[id] return dict(extension=self._translate(req, id, ext))

commit_message:
Add None as one of valid ipv6 attributes

According to https://www.dropbox.com/s/9bojvv9vywsz8sd/
IPv6%20Two%20Modes%20v3.0.pdf
(or blueprint: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102411/) 
flag "Off" is valid IPv6 attribute state. Should be 
explicit way to send it as "Off". Now it's impossible, 
you should miss it if you want it "Off".
Later it's checked and treated as "attribute not set" 
if None.

Change-Id: If4efb5f7d20ad901dd757e7efe05a08bc0039462

subject: Endpoint Authentication via X509 Certificates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-13 04:18:35.000000000', 'files': ['specs/juno/endpoint-cert.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs/commit/0396e6408e78203be13189608cfc807654cb8d58', 'message': 'Endpoint Authentication via X509 Certificates

Change-Id: Ifadd8ee4d824605f189eb1ebb1909de68d612750
'}]
commit_message:
Endpoint Authentication via X509 Certificates

Change-Id: Ifadd8ee4d824605f189eb1ebb1909de68d612750
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/37/99837/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Endpoint Authentication X509 Certificates ========================================== `bp example <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/endpoint-cert>`_ Allow endpoints to authenticate via X509 certificates specific to each endpoint. Problem Description =================== Endpoints need to be able to authenticate to Keystone to perform actions that are specific to endpoints: fetch the token revocation information, and fetch their policy files. Reusing a service user across multipl endpoint has security implications. Instea, each end point should have its own identity. Proposed Change =============== We treat endpoints like users; instead of one set of credentials that is copied to each Nova etc we give each a distinct Identity. They should be using an X509 to authenticate to Keystone. The X509 can be self signed by the endpoint for all we really care, although it means that we will have a bunch of CAs. Better to have them issued by Keystone by default. It has to be x509 for PKI because you can't do SSH style plain key based authentication on the web and Kerberos is too high a barrier to entry. However, this approach should be extensible to Kerberos in a separate blueprint. Even with eventlet we can do X509 based client auth. Endpoints credentials will be kept in an new column in the endpoint table. Upon or after an endpoint is registered, an admin will upload a Client Certificate for the endpoint. This sounds like it _needs_ barbican (or something similar for the services cert management/ca) for a professional deployment. endpoints would then act as users (using a token to get the policy, etc)? and use those credentials to get policy ,and also to get revocation lists etc. Tokens issued this way shoud not have a user_id in it. They should have the endpoint_id in them instead. Use the current auth endpoint or add another? Another; It only accepts client certs, and only checks them against endpoints. Add an additional CLI for devstack to issue the X509 certificates. pki_setup and ssl_setup are already hacks. This would be an additional hack just like them: keystone_manage sign_endpoint_cert. Make it a stand alone CLI operation to start, and then after you register the endpoint, have an api "upload cert for endpoint" we could roll the service users into the endpoint table The endpoint ID and service name should be in the X509, but that is not a hard requirement. Alternatives ------------ Create one service user per endpoint. This will break in AD cases where Identity is read only. it will work if we put some users in SQL, but it means that endpoint are going to use Paswords, which is not a secure authentication mechanism. X509 and user authentication could be built the same way. The Endpoint ID could be the endpoint user id, and then we have a user per endpoint, if the service users go in their own domain. Data Model Impact ----------------- Add a Certificate field to the endpoint table. REST API Impact --------------- POST /ednpointcert body of the post should be the X509 for the endpoint. Security Impact --------------- Ovewrall should tighent up security: PKI is less vulnerable than passwords. It will require more X509 infrastrucutre in the Keystone server: both SSL by default and X50-9 client certificate checking are handled wlell by apache modules. But they can be done via Eventlet if needed. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- There will need to be corresponding changes to keystone client to take advantage of the,m Performance Impact ------------------ SSL in eventlet is slow. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- More x509 generation, which will benfit from a real CA solution. Developer Impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ayoung Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== References ==========

commit_message:
If no volume, don't delete volume in teardown

If exception is thrown in setupClass before volume is created,
tearDownClass needn't delete volume.

Change-Id: I91c7eff8ec147b0ce3a9ea3e6c8d906ba68412c2
Closes-Bug: 1350167

added_lines: import base64 import httplib from neutron.common import log as call_log from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging from neutron.openstack.common import jsonutils as json LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) RESP_STATUS = 0 RESP_REASON = 1 RESP_STR = 2 RESP_DATA = 3 class vDirectRESTClient: """REST server proxy to Radware vDirect.""" @call_log.log def __init__(self, server='localhost', secondary_server=None, user=None, password=None, port=2189, ssl=True, timeout=5000, base_uri=''): self.server = server self.secondary_server = secondary_server self.port = port self.ssl = ssl self.base_uri = base_uri self.timeout = timeout if user and password: self.auth = base64.encodestring('%s:%s' % (user, password)) self.auth = self.auth.replace('\n', '') else: raise r_exc.AuthenticationMissing() debug_params = {'server': self.server, 'sec_server': self.secondary_server, 'port': self.port, 'ssl': self.ssl} LOG.debug(_('vDirectRESTClient:init server=%(server)s, ' 'secondary server=%(sec_server)s, ' 'port=%(port)d, ' 'ssl=%(ssl)r'), debug_params) def _flip_servers(self): LOG.warning(_('Fliping servers. Current is: %(server)s, ' 'switching to %(secondary)s'), {'server': self.server, 'secondary': self.secondary_server}) self.server, self.secondary_server = self.secondary_server, self.server def _recover(self, action, resource, data, headers, binary=False): if self.server and self.secondary_server: self._flip_servers() resp = self._call(action, resource, data, headers, binary) return resp else: LOG.exception(_('REST client is not able to recover ' 'since only one vDirect server is ' 'configured.')) return -1, None, None, None def call(self, action, resource, data, headers, binary=False): resp = self._call(action, resource, data, headers, binary) if resp[RESP_STATUS] == -1: LOG.warning(_('vDirect server is not responding (%s).'), self.server) return self._recover(action, resource, data, headers, binary) elif resp[RESP_STATUS] in (301, 307): LOG.warning(_('vDirect server is not active (%s).'), self.server) return self._recover(action, resource, data, headers, binary) else: return resp @call_log.log def _call(self, action, resource, data, headers, binary=False): if resource.startswith('http'): uri = resource else: uri = self.base_uri + resource if binary: body = data else: body = json.dumps(data) debug_data = 'binary' if binary else body debug_data = debug_data if debug_data else 'EMPTY' if not headers: headers = {'Authorization': 'Basic %s' % self.auth} else: headers['Authorization'] = 'Basic %s' % self.auth conn = None if self.ssl: conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: LOG.error(_('vdirectRESTClient: Could not establish HTTPS ' 'connection')) return 0, None, None, None else: conn = httplib.HTTPConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: LOG.error(_('vdirectRESTClient: Could not establish HTTP ' 'connection')) return 0, None, None, None try: conn.request(action, uri, body, headers) response = conn.getresponse() respstr = response.read() respdata = respstr try: respdata = json.loads(respstr) except ValueError: # response was not JSON, ignore the exception pass ret = (response.status, response.reason, respstr, respdata) except Exception as e: log_dict = {'action': action, 'e': e} LOG.error(_('vdirectRESTClient: %(action)s failure, %(e)r'), log_dict) ret = -1, None, None, None conn.close() return ret

commit_message:
Enhance V3 extension class to use resources

RESTful APIs are resource-oriented, and the V3 extensions each
provide a RESTful API, but the current way that extensions map their
routes is based on URLs rather than resources. With this change, the
base V3 extensions class is enhanced to support a resource-oriented
way to map paths to controllers and methods.

bp json-home

commit_message:
Avoid duplication of discovery for multi-sink sources

Perviously, where a single source has a pluggable discovery
extension loaded and is associated with multiple sinks, the
discovered resources were duplicated for each sink.

Now, we ensure that duplicate discovery extensions are
excluded.

Change-Id: Icffcc65f2be2baef7730b31773b39ffdda0454a7
Closes-Bug: #1354536

commit_message:
Hello world sample enhancement

Did following changes:

1. Using OS::Nova::Server instead of AWS::EC2::Instance,
2. Naming in snake style instead of cammel style,
3. Make use of the two unused parameters.

Change-Id: Idf8a1cb3df9fde1cbbd21c931aec3988aa9d7140

Since we update the template incrementally during an update, after a failed
update we cannot determine what the last used properties of a resource were
just from the template (since e.g. the parameter values may have changed).

resource needs to be updated.

Implements: partial-blueprint update-failure-recovery
'}]
commit_message:
Diff against stored properties during update

Since we update the template incrementally during an update, after a failed
update we cannot determine what the last used properties of a resource were
just from the template (since e.g. the parameter values may have changed).
Use the property data stored in the database instead to determine whether a
resource needs to be updated.

Change-Id: I41f191265186fc3bcec1670403fd16a80c509740
Implements: partial-blueprint update-failure-recovery

commit_message:
Avoid naming time type module the same as a builtin

In order to avoid naming conflicts which can easily
occur if we name our time module as a python builtin
just pick a name that doesn't conflict (it still
retains the same meaning).

Change-Id: Ia19f3776689d2b1f31f7cbfaa15e53f99a3ee900

commit_message:
Remove need to do special exception catching in parse_uri

The upstream oslo incubator code was fixed to not throw a
index error when parts of the uri are missing, so we can
remove our modification that handles these errors and just
rely on the fixed version.

Change-Id: I01c6a647858ca45aeb4685a68cb3e28b575e1e05

subject: Fix rebuild with cells
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-25 16:22:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/edef2cd5588ddf23b2a3cf0ac38d6368600b3c25', 'message': 'Fix rebuild with cells

This is a temporary commit to solicit feedback.

Change-Id: Ic1c575fbca72f1cd34b1dbc6f82023e5b2b392e2
Closes-Bug: 1348642
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-07-25 20:26:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cb79ff748b3b24695181128b5f808d3ed768b4a2', 'message': "Fix rebuild with cells

When rebuild_instances switched to a compute task it broke
cells since the cast was dropped as it didn't match.

This change moves the rebuild_instances to conductor and
also adds some unit tests checks on the compute
task integration point.

commit_message:
Fix rebuild with cells

When rebuild_instances switched to a compute task it broke
cells since the cast was dropped as it didn't match.

This change moves the rebuild_instances to conductor and
also adds some unit tests checks on the compute
task integration point.

Change-Id: Ic1c575fbca72f1cd34b1dbc6f82023e5b2b392e2
Closes-Bug: 1348642

commit_message:
Makes versions API output deterministic

Makes the order of available versions that the API version
information is returned to clients deterministic. This is
necessary to ensure that with PYTHONHASHSEED to fixed to 0 the
unittests will consistently pass.

Change-Id: I5b7f6b7f061424adc2263c485562e72c7cc29255
Partial-Bug: #1350287

commit_message:
Allow tests to run outside tox

When using a test runner outside of tox (for example
using py.test directly against test files, one of several
ways to enable faster and more specific testing)
oslo.messaging.conffixture is not imported and text/base fails
to compile.

This change gets things working and otherwise has no impact.

Change-Id: Ibac6ae0a73aa55522b248a26b9a4b82455f8fce6

commit_message:
Use adapter from keystoneclient

SessionClient is mostly common code that wasn't yet released in
keystoneclient. Now that 0.10 is released we should use the adapter from
there as much as possible.

Change-Id: Ief6cd7e752fd8c9e9157364f99e270da7faff074

deleted_lines: class SessionClient(object): def __init__(self, session, auth, interface, service_type, region_name): self.session = session self.auth = auth self.interface = interface self.service_type = service_type self.region_name = region_name kwargs.setdefault('user_agent', 'python-novaclient') kwargs.setdefault('auth', self.auth) kwargs.setdefault('authenticated', False) try: kwargs['json'] = kwargs.pop('body') except KeyError: pass headers = kwargs.setdefault('headers', {}) headers.setdefault('Accept', 'application/json') endpoint_filter = kwargs.setdefault('endpoint_filter', {}) endpoint_filter.setdefault('interface', self.interface) endpoint_filter.setdefault('service_type', self.service_type) endpoint_filter.setdefault('region_name', self.region_name) resp = self.session.request(url, method, raise_exc=False, **kwargs) body = None if resp.text: try: body = resp.json() except ValueError: pass def _cs_request(self, url, method, **kwargs): # this function is mostly redundant but makes compatibility easier kwargs.setdefault('authenticated', True) return self.request(url, method, **kwargs) def get(self, url, **kwargs): return self._cs_request(url, 'GET', **kwargs) def post(self, url, **kwargs): return self._cs_request(url, 'POST', **kwargs) def put(self, url, **kwargs): return self._cs_request(url, 'PUT', **kwargs) def delete(self, url, **kwargs): return self._cs_request(url, 'DELETE', **kwargs) auth=None): region_name=region_name)

commit_message:
libvirt: Removed unused `disk_images` parameter

`disk_images` isn't used in `_create_image` so we can remove it and simplify
the code a bit.

Change-Id: Ida26135d7d1ffb3f3ae77e560ce246f03fd76ef5

commit_message:
ssl-ca: Allow CA certificate to be specified

Allow a CA certificate to be specified, and automatically add it to
the default system CA bundle via a new "ssl-ca" DIB element.

This is required for sites which use their own Certificate Authority.

This DIB element is safe to include on all images, regardless of
whether or not it is activated with a valid CA certificate.

Based on SSL PKI spec:
  I32473fe797a4c1e28d14c3b82c8892c7c59a4e55

Depends on t-h-t update for ssl.ca_certificate property via Heat:
  Ibacd7c98980520e11c0df89632013f2ba2dbe370

Change-Id: I3441b4b688aacb2bb8d8326ee72f87974dd554ff

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. set -eux set -o pipefail if [[ "ubuntu debian" =~ "$DISTRO_NAME" ]]; then update-ca-certificates else openssl x509 -text -in /etc/ssl/from-heat-ca.crt >> /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt fi

subject: Fix order of arguments in assertEqual
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-21 10:06:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/6880883857a51cf8959571c02fac9ef08dd50b14', 'message': 'Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is...

    def assertEqual(self, expected, observed, message=''):
        """Assert that 'expected' is equal to 'observed'.

        :param expected: The expected value.
        :param observed: The observed value.
        :param message: An optional message to include in the error.
        """

The string length of the sum of the results of repr(expected) and

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is...

    def assertEqual(self, expected, observed, message=''):
        """Assert that 'expected' is equal to 'observed'.

        :param expected: The expected value.
        :param observed: The observed value.
        :param message: An optional message to include in the error.
        """

The string length of the sum of the results of repr(expected) and
repr(observed) is greater than 70, then, MismatchError message is
changed, as below.

  Ex.:
        raise mismatch_error
    MismatchError: !=:
    reference = '_123456789_123456789_bar'
    actual    = '_123456789_123456789_123456789_123456789_123456789'

I think the case of Cinder, where correction is immense. Please also
consider the cost of the review itself in the future.

Change-Id: Idbe5368ba558b4cf8d2ed99af255f94d48986c33
Partial-Bug: #1259292

commit_message:
Replace HTTPSConnection in zadara with Requests

SSL Verification is from now on enabled by default.

This changes the default behaviour and is the primary intention of this
change: verify SSL certificates.

This might break existing configuration/setups where the SSL certificate
used by the SAN would not pass the verification.

Old behaviour can be forced by using `san_ssl_insecure=True`.

SecurityImpact
DocImpact
Partial-Bug: 1188189

Change-Id: I4799c2c5376fb54e5ebbdc4f9b6a1c526e7b8a8b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/46/77346/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import netaddr import requests host = self.conf.zadara_vpsa_ip port = self.conf.zadara_vpsa_port verify = self.conf.san_ssl_cafile or True if self.conf.san_ssl_insecure: verify = False if netaddr.valid_ipv6(host): # NOTE(dgollub): Taken from keystone-client # it is an IPv6 address, so it needs to be wrapped # with '[]' to generate a valid IPv6 URL, based on # http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2732.txt host = '[%s]' % host protocol = "http" if self.conf.zadara_vpsa_use_ssl: protocol = "https" if port: api_url = "%s://%s:%d%s" % (protocol, host, port, url) else: api_url = "%s://%s%s" % (protocol, host, url) response = requests.request(method, api_url, data=body, verify=verify) if response.status_code != 200: raise exception.BadHTTPResponseStatus(status=response.status_code) data = response.text
deleted_lines: import httplib if self.conf.zadara_vpsa_use_ssl: connection = httplib.HTTPSConnection(self.conf.zadara_vpsa_ip, self.conf.zadara_vpsa_port) else: connection = httplib.HTTPConnection(self.conf.zadara_vpsa_ip, self.conf.zadara_vpsa_port) connection.request(method, url, body) response = connection.getresponse() if response.status != 200: connection.close() raise exception.BadHTTPResponseStatus(status=response.status) data = response.read() connection.close()

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-03 14:19:42.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/openstack/common/db/sqlalchemy/session.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/89c10f8bba7be12f9f62126a767ddbbc5c5733ae', 'message': 'Add _wrap_db_error support for postgresql

We need to add support for postgresql.

The deadlock exception thrown from postgresql is TransactionRollbackError,
it's not the same with "OperationalError" thrown from mysql,
and isn't included in sqlalchemy. So, the base exception need to be
catched.

commit_message:
Add _wrap_db_error support for postgresql

The original "_wrap_db_error" function is only available for mysql.
We need to add support for postgresql.

The deadlock exception thrown from postgresql is TransactionRollbackError,
it's not the same with "OperationalError" thrown from mysql,
and isn't included in sqlalchemy. So, the base exception need to be
catched.

Sync postgresql deadlock bug from oslo.db,
it's submit SHA-1: 3a6a5b01a72e0e20787f3d6a47f6f0c0262dbbeb

Change-Id: I17ddc82586db317d4ce9ac87c803a3667872bcac
Closes-Bug: #1331942
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/62/104562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except sqla_exc.DBAPIError as e: # NOTE(wingwj): This branch is used to catch deadlock exception # under postgresql. The original exception thrown from postgresql # is TransactionRollbackError, it's not included in the sqlalchemy. # Moreover, DBAPIError is the base class of OperationalError # and IntegrityError, so we catch it on the end of the process. # # The issue has also submitted to sqlalchemy on # https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/sqlalchemy/issue/3075/ # support-non-standard-dbapi-exception # (FIXME) This branch should be refactored after the patch # merged in & our requirement of sqlalchemy updated _raise_if_db_connection_lost(e, self.bind) _raise_if_deadlock_error(e, self.bind.dialect.name) LOG.exception(_LE('DBAPIError exception wrapped from %s') % e) raise exception.DBError(e)

commit_message:
Fixes cinder quota-show information with wrong tenant-id

quota-show displays the default information eventhough specified
tenant-id does not exists:

  cinder quota-show wrong_tenant_id

The fix has been applied so that quota-show with wrong tenant-id will
display an error with "TenantID not found"

Change-Id: I9e32ed32f761a59746222aa2a1cafb05802847b7
Closes-Bug: #1307475

subject: Change volume and snapshot stuck creating to error

the status of the 'creating'.

Status of the volume is still 'creating' even if

commit_message:
Change volume and snapshot stuck creating to error

Service of volume goes down after the status of
the volume is turned 'creating', volume to remain with
the status of the 'creating'.

Status of the volume is still 'creating' even if
volume service is restarted, it is impossible for user
to remove it without force-delete.

With this patch, in order to keep consistence with Nova,
volume state 'creating' should be shifted to the error properly.

Change-Id: I777ee0c809415077106ff2e6afe5a2c88670a773
Closes-Bug: #1310526

added_lines: def test_volume_fails_with_creating_status(self): """Test that while creating volume, volume process down and stuck in 'creating' status. """ volume = tests_utils.create_volume(self.context, status='creating', size=0, host=CONF.host) volume_id = volume['id'] self.volume.init_host() volume = db.volume_get(context.get_admin_context(), volume_id) self.assertEqual(volume['status'], "error") self.volume.delete_volume(self.context, volume_id) def test_create_snapshot_fails_with_creating_status(self): """Test that while creating snapshot, volume process down and stuck in 'creating' status. """ volume = tests_utils.create_volume(self.context, **self.volume_params) snapshot = tests_utils.create_snapshot(self.context, volume['id'], status='creating') snap_id = snapshot['id'] self.volume.init_host() snap_ref = db.snapshot_get(context.get_admin_context(), snap_id) self.assertEqual(snap_ref['status'], "error") self.volume.delete_snapshot(self.context, snap_id) self.volume.delete_volume(self.context, volume['id'])

commit_message:
Show volume dependent snap-id list while deleting

I have added change which display snapshot list in error
message to the volume being deleted also I have validated
the data being returned.

Closes-Bug: #1276101
Change-Id: I42f6a50669463146e46e5b0951d1e91b9a4d24bc

commit_message:
Disable volume copy bandwidth limit for specified disks

This patch adds a new config option "volume_copy_no_limit_devices" to
disable volume copy bandwidth limit for specified disks here. This is
useful to avoid the throttling for local disks of the cinder volume
node which doesn't affect volume access performance of instances.

Change-Id: I985765d5305247eaf6065f206e41e7f6c941a5c5
Closes-Bug: 1348276
DocImpact: new config option 'volume_copy_no_limit_devices'

commit_message:
Add ProphetStor Federator Volume Driver for cinder

ProphetStor Federator is a software-defined storage platform that
supports multiple storage back-ends to enhance Cinder
functionalities. Federator abstracts, pools, and automatically
provisions the appropriate type of storage based on the selected
Cinder volume-type.

Change-Id: If411e49b0ffd8da3f9ced9936c8750d59418ea80
Implements: blueprint prophetstor-federator-driver
cinder-cert-result: http://download.prophetstor.com/cinder-cert-results/tmp.vOAdhQdDsy

commit_message:
Harden tgtadm chap authentication

When using LVMISCSIDriver and iscsi_helper tgtadm,
it should support chap unidirectional authentication
because target configuration file and db.volume has
record chap user and chap passwd.
By testing, tgtadm iscsi chap does not work.

We should fix the bug by setting user/passwd and binding it
to relative tid before leaving leaving the function
TgtAdm:create_iscsi_target, so as to harden chap authentication.

Change-Id: I1cd56aab4f58c27010a1a2eb77d56673b9d829b3
Closes-Bug: #1329214
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/20/102420/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: type, name, passwd = chap_auth.split() self.bind_user_passwd_tid(name, passwd, tid) def bind_user_passwd_tid(self, name, passwd, tid): try: self._execute('tgtadm', '--lld', 'iscsi', '--mode', 'account', '--op', 'new', '--user', name, '--password', passwd) self._execute('tgtadm', '--lld', 'iscsi', '--mode', 'account', '--op', 'bind', '--tid', tid, '--user', name ) except putils.ProcessExecutionError: LOG.warning(_("Failed to create chap user/passwd for iscsi target " "tid:%(tid)n") % {'tid': tid})

commit_message:
set default auth_strategy to keystone

Like in change Ife63dc7ab680fcf0588d95c98fc9f29901485c64 for Nova
the default for auth_strategy should be keystone instead of noauth.

DocImpact Changed default config option 'auth_strategy' to 'keystone'.

Change-Id: I112e26446b2c62abd633ee68ae7d9b24925e9936
Closes-Bug: #1327503

commit_message:
Add volume driver for Huawei 18000 storage system

Huawei OceanStor 18000-series enterprise storage system is an optimum
storage platform for next-generation data centers that feature
virtualization, hybrid cloud, simplified IT, and low carbon footprints.

This patch add an iSCSI driver and a FC driver for Huawei 18000 storage
system, using REST. We define a common module for both iSCSI driver and
FC driver.

Change-Id: I0325aac53f6eb2691ed6057f81d6aeb8c794c789
Implements: blueprint huawei-18000-driver

commit_message:
Fix missing clone_image API support for sheepdog driver.

if image is backend by sheepdog, it will use create_cloned_volume
function to help to clone this image. Normally sheepdog can clone
only from snapshot.

Closes-Bug: #1140177
Change-Id: Ibd355082e7c3215c00f6576404566577f7a2601c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/89/90789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _is_cloneable(self, image_location, image_meta): """check the image can be clone or not.""" cloneable = False # check whether volume is stored in sheepdog try: image_id = image_meta['id'] self._try_execute('collie', 'vdi', 'list', "%s" % image_id) cloneable = True except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Can not find vdi %(image)s: %(err)s") % dict( image=image_id, err=e)) return cloneable def clone_image(self, volume, image_location, image_id, image_meta): """Create a volume efficiently from an existing image.""" if not self._is_cloneable(image_location, image_meta): return {}, False volume_ref = {'name': image_id, 'size': image_meta['size']} self.create_cloned_volume(volume, volume_ref) self._resize(volume) vol_path = self.local_path(volume) return {'provider_location': vol_path}, True def create_cloned_volume(self, volume, src_vref): """Clone a sheepdog volume from another volume.""" snapshot_name = src_vref['name'] + '-temp-snapshot' volumesize = src_vref['size'] snapshot = { 'name': snapshot_name, 'volume_name': src_vref['name'], 'volume_size': volumesize, } self.create_snapshot(snapshot) try: # Create volume self.create_volume_from_snapshot(volume, snapshot) except Exception: msg = (_('Failed to create cloned volume %s'), volume['name']) LOG.error(msg) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(msg) finally: # Delete temp Snapshot self.delete_snapshot(snapshot)
deleted_lines: def create_cloned_volume(self, volume, src_vref): raise NotImplementedError()

commit_message:
Add a method _get_ssl_config to save the ssl configurations

When the SSL configurations have been read once, save them into ssl_kwargs
for further use.

Change-Id: I6fe02251b60a873a644f0fcdbba9ea6cac657919
closes-bug: #1301448
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/73/105073/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ssl_kwargs = None @staticmethod def get_ssl_kwargs(): if not Server._status_to_type: # read the ssl cert_file = CONF.ssl_cert_file key_file = CONF.ssl_key_file ca_file = CONF.ssl_ca_file use_ssl = cert_file or key_file if cert_file and not os.path.exists(cert_file): raise RuntimeError(_("Unable to find cert_file : %s") % cert_file) if ca_file and not os.path.exists(ca_file): raise RuntimeError(_("Unable to find ca_file : %s") % ca_file) if key_file and not os.path.exists(key_file): raise RuntimeError(_("Unable to find key_file : %s") % key_file) if use_ssl and (not cert_file or not key_file): raise RuntimeError(_("When running server in SSL mode, you must " "specify both a cert_file and key_file " "option value in your configuration file")) Server.ssl_kwargs = { 'server_side': True, 'certfile': cert_file, 'keyfile': key_file, 'cert_reqs': ssl.CERT_NONE, 'use_ssl': use_ssl, } if CONF.ssl_ca_file: Server.ssl_kwargs['ca_certs'] = ca_file Server.ssl_kwargs['cert_reqs'] = ssl.CERT_REQUIRED return Server.ssl_kwargs else: return Server.ssl_kwargs def wrap_ssl(sock): ssl_kwargs = self.get_ssl_kwargs() if ssl_kwargs['use_ssl']: return ssl.wrap_socket(sock, **ssl_kwargs) else: return sock sock = wrap_ssl(sock)
deleted_lines: cert_file = CONF.ssl_cert_file key_file = CONF.ssl_key_file ca_file = CONF.ssl_ca_file use_ssl = cert_file or key_file if cert_file and not os.path.exists(cert_file): raise RuntimeError(_("Unable to find cert_file : %s") % cert_file) if ca_file and not os.path.exists(ca_file): raise RuntimeError(_("Unable to find ca_file : %s") % ca_file) if key_file and not os.path.exists(key_file): raise RuntimeError(_("Unable to find key_file : %s") % key_file) if use_ssl and (not cert_file or not key_file): raise RuntimeError(_("When running server in SSL mode, you must " "specify both a cert_file and key_file " "option value in your configuration file")) def wrap_ssl(sock): ssl_kwargs = { 'server_side': True, 'certfile': cert_file, 'keyfile': key_file, 'cert_reqs': ssl.CERT_NONE, } if CONF.ssl_ca_file: ssl_kwargs['ca_certs'] = ca_file ssl_kwargs['cert_reqs'] = ssl.CERT_REQUIRED return ssl.wrap_socket(sock, **ssl_kwargs) if use_ssl: sock = wrap_ssl(sock)

subject: Allow a volume to be rolled back to its snapshot
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-02 15:31:53.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/manager.py', 'cinder/volume/driver.py', 'cinder/volume/rpcapi.py', 'cinder/api/contrib/volume_actions.py', 'cinder/volume/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/ba190c683095a2bcbec1a2fdff115ab9547b30d5', 'message': 'Allow a volume to be rolled back to its snapshot

It makes sense to be able to revert a volume to a previously
taken snapshot. The roll-back function can be used to revert
 a volume to a previous snapshot, restoring the volume to
 the state at the time the snapshot was taken. The function
supports roll-back to any previously taken snapshot on the
volume (we will call it the roll-back snapshot in this
document to distinguish it from other snapshots).

The roll-back process will overwrite the existing volume with
data from the rollback snapshot; all other snapshots taken
after the rollback snapshot will be deleted.

Note
The volume that for the roll-back must be detached if it is
attached to a Nova VM.

Change-Id: If8e22ba4762a97d324afdcbde0b8731a3d7d898c
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-rollback-snapshot
'}]
commit_message:
Allow a volume to be rolled back to its snapshot

It makes sense to be able to revert a volume to a previously
taken snapshot. The roll-back function can be used to revert
 a volume to a previous snapshot, restoring the volume to
 the state at the time the snapshot was taken. The function
supports roll-back to any previously taken snapshot on the
volume (we will call it the roll-back snapshot in this
document to distinguish it from other snapshots).

The roll-back process will overwrite the existing volume with
data from the rollback snapshot; all other snapshots taken
after the rollback snapshot will be deleted.

Note
The volume that for the roll-back must be detached if it is
attached to a Nova VM.

Change-Id: If8e22ba4762a97d324afdcbde0b8731a3d7d898c
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-rollback-snapshot
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/33/104233/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Implement zfs driver.

blueprint zfs-based-iscsi-san
blueprint zfsonlinux-volume-driver

This driver has been tested on Linux and FreeBSD. It includes a
snapshot-based image-cache.

Change-Id: Ieef1a58b78bba75147fcfb0d406abaa4a3fdf711
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/92/92092/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright 2010 United States Government as represented by the # Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. # All Rights Reserved. # # Copyright 2013 CloudVPS # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Driver for Linux servers running ZFS. """ import math import socket import time from oslo.config import cfg from cinder.brick import exception as brick_exception from cinder import exception from cinder.image import image_utils from cinder.openstack.common import fileutils from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder.openstack.common import processutils as putils from cinder.openstack.common import strutils from cinder import utils from cinder.volume import driver LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) volume_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('zfs_zpool', default='cinder-volumes', help='Name for the zpool that will contain exported volumes'), ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(volume_opts) def _sizestr(size_in_g): if int(size_in_g) == 0: return '100m' return '%sg' % size_in_g def _fromsizestr(sizestr, default=0): # ZFS uses a dash as a 'not applicable' value. if sizestr == '-': return None # ZFS tools give their sizes as 1T, 9.2G. string_to_bytes # doesn't accept that format, so we'll have to add a B. try: return strutils.string_to_bytes(sizestr + "B") except ValueError: return strutils.string_to_bytes(sizestr) class ZFSVolumeDriver(driver.VolumeDriver): """Executes commands relating to Volumes.""" VERSION = '1.0.0' def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(ZFSVolumeDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.hostname = socket.gethostname() self.zpool = self.configuration.zfs_zpool self.backend_name =\ self.configuration.safe_get('volume_backend_name') or 'ZFS' self.protocol = 'local' def set_execute(self, execute): self._execute = execute def check_for_setup_error(self): """Verify that requirements are in place to use ZFS driver.""" # Call zpool, if the volume doesn't exist it will result in an error self._execute('zpool', 'status', self.zpool, run_as_root=True) def create_volume(self, volume): """Creates a logical volume.""" if not self.volume_exists(volume): self._execute('zfs', 'create', '-s', # sparse '-V', _sizestr(volume['size']), "%s/%s" % (self.zpool, volume['name']), run_as_root=True) def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, volume, snapshot): """Creates a volume from a snapshot.""" # FIXME: this will fail if the volume already exists, which may happen # during a retry cycle. src_path = "%s/%s@%s" % (self.zpool, snapshot['volume_name'], snapshot['name']) dst_path = "%s/%s" % (self.zpool, volume['name']) self._execute('zfs', 'clone', src_path, dst_path, run_as_root=True) def _delete_volume(self, volume): """Deletes a logical volume.""" full_name = "%s/%s" % (self.zpool, volume['name']) try: # Try to promote dependent volumes stdout, stderr = self._execute('zfs', 'get', '-H', '-r', '-t', 'snapshot', 'clones', full_name, run_as_root=True) for line in stdout.splitlines(): if not line: continue clones = line.split('\t')[2] if clones and clones != '-': for clone in clones.split(','): self._execute('zfs', 'promote', clone, run_as_root=True) self._execute('zfs', 'destroy', '-r', full_name, run_as_root=True) return True except putils.ProcessExecutionError as err: if "dataset is busy" in err.stderr: mesg = (_('Unable to delete volume %s due to it being busy') % volume['name']) LOG.error(mesg) raise exception.VolumeIsBusy(volume_name=volume['name']) elif "dataset does not exist" not in err.stderr: mesg = (_('Error reported running zfs destroy: ' 'CMD: %(command)s, RESPONSE: %(response)s') % {'command': err.cmd, 'response': err.stderr}) LOG.error(mesg) raise def delete_volume(self, volume): for attempt in range(3): try: return self._delete_volume(volume) except exception.VolumeIsBusy: if attempt != 2: time.sleep(15) else: raise def clear_volume(self, volume, is_snapshot=False): """unprovision old volumes to prevent data leaking between users.""" pass # not useful or necessary on ZFS def create_snapshot(self, snapshot): """Creates a snapshot.""" cmd = ['zfs', 'snapshot', "%s/%s@%s" % (self.zpool, snapshot['volume_name'], snapshot['name'])] try: self._execute(*cmd, run_as_root=True) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as err: LOG.exception(_('Error creating snapshot')) LOG.error(_('Cmd :%s') % err.cmd) LOG.error(_('StdOut :%s') % err.stdout) LOG.error(_('StdErr :%s') % err.stderr) raise def delete_snapshot(self, snapshot): """Deletes a snapshot.""" full_name = "%s/%s@%s" % (self.zpool, snapshot['volume_name'], snapshot['name']) try: self._execute('zfs', 'destroy', "-d", full_name, run_as_root=True) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as err: if "volume has children" in err.stderr: mesg = (_('Unable to delete snapshot due to dependent ' 'snapshots for volume: %s') % full_name) LOG.error(mesg) raise exception.VolumeIsBusy( volume_name=snapshot['volume_name']) elif "dataset does not exist" not in err.stderr: mesg = (_('Error reported running zfs destroy: ' 'CMD: %(command)s, RESPONSE: %(response)s') % {'command': err.cmd, 'response': err.stderr}) LOG.error(mesg) raise def volume_exists(self, volume): full_name = "%s/%s" % (self.zpool, volume['name']) try: self._execute('zfs', 'list', full_name, run_as_root=True) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as err: if 'dataset does not exist' in err.stderr: return False raise return True def snapshot_exists(self, snapshot): if self.volume_exists({'name': snapshot['volume_name']}): snapshots = self.list_snapshots({'name': snapshot['volume_name']}) return any(s['name'] == snapshot['name'] for s in snapshots) return False def list_snapshots(self, volume): full_name = "%s/%s" % (self.zpool, volume['name']) (out, err) = self._execute('zfs', 'list', '-t', 'snapshot', '-r', '-H', full_name, run_as_root=True) result = [] for line in out.splitlines(): name, used, available, referenced, mountpoint = line.split() result.append({ 'name': name.split('@')[-1], 'volume_name': name.split('/', 1)[1], 'zpool': name.split('/')[0], 'used': _fromsizestr(used), 'available': _fromsizestr(available), 'referenced': _fromsizestr(referenced), 'mountpoint': mountpoint, }) return result def local_path(self, volume): return "/dev/zvol/%s/%s" % (self.zpool, volume['name']) @utils.synchronized('zfs-imgcache', external=False) def copy_image_to_volume(self, context, volume, image_service, image_id): """Fetch the image from image_service and write it to the volume.""" img_cache_volume = {'name': 'img-%s' % image_id} img_cache_snapshot = {'volume_name': img_cache_volume['name'], 'name': 'snap'} if self.list_snapshots(volume): # If the volume has snapshots, there is no efficient way to replace # the contents. Do things the inefficient way. image_utils.fetch_to_raw(context, image_service, image_id, self.local_path(volume), self.configuration.volume_dd_blocksize, size=volume['size']) else: if not self.snapshot_exists(img_cache_snapshot): with image_utils.temporary_file() as tmp: image_utils.fetch_verify_image(context, image_service, image_id, tmp) qemu_info = image_utils.qemu_img_info(tmp) virtual_size_gb = math.ceil( qemu_info.virtual_size / 1024.0**3) img_cache_volume['size'] = virtual_size_gb self.create_volume(img_cache_volume) image_utils.convert_image( tmp, self.local_path(img_cache_volume), 'raw', sparse=64*1024) self.create_snapshot(img_cache_snapshot) self.delete_volume(volume) self.create_volume_from_snapshot(volume, img_cache_snapshot) self.extend_volume(volume, volume['size']) def copy_volume_to_image(self, context, volume, image_service, image_meta): """Copy the volume to the specified image.""" image_utils.upload_volume(context, image_service, image_meta, self.local_path(volume)) def create_cloned_volume(self, volume, src_vref): """Creates a clone of the specified volume.""" volume_name = src_vref['name'] temp_snapshot = {'volume_name': volume_name, 'name': 'origin-%s' % volume['id']} self.create_snapshot(temp_snapshot) self.create_volume_from_snapshot(volume, temp_snapshot) @utils.synchronized('zfs-imgcache', external=False) def clone_image(self, volume, image_location, image_id, image_meta): img_cache_snapshot = {'volume_name': 'img-%s' % image_id, 'name': 'snap'} if self.snapshot_exists(img_cache_snapshot): self.create_volume_from_snapshot(volume, img_cache_snapshot) self.extend_volume(volume, volume['size']) return None, True return None, False def backup_volume(self, context, backup, backup_service): """Create a new backup from an existing volume.""" volume = self.db.volume_get(context, backup['volume_id']) volume_path = self.local_path(volume) with utils.temporary_chown(volume_path): with fileutils.file_open(volume_path) as volume_file: backup_service.backup(backup, volume_file) def restore_backup(self, context, backup, volume, backup_service): """Restore an existing backup to a new or existing volume.""" volume_path = self.local_path(volume) with utils.temporary_chown(volume_path): with fileutils.file_open(volume_path, 'wb') as volume_file: backup_service.restore(backup, volume['id'], volume_file) def get_volume_stats(self, refresh=False): """Get volume status. If 'refresh' is True, run update the stats first. """ if refresh: self._update_volume_stats() return self._stats def _update_volume_stats(self): """Retrieve stats info from volume group.""" out, err = self._execute('zpool', 'list', '-H', "-oname,free,size", self.zpool, run_as_root=True) name, avail, size = out.strip().split('\t') data = {} # Note(zhiteng): These information are driver/backend specific, # each driver may define these values in its own config options # or fetch from driver specific configuration file. data["volume_backend_name"] = self.backend_name data["vendor_name"] = 'Open Source' data["driver_version"] = self.VERSION data["storage_protocol"] = self.protocol gb_factor = 1.0 / (1024 ** 3) data['total_capacity_gb'] = _fromsizestr(size) * gb_factor data['free_capacity_gb'] = _fromsizestr(avail) * gb_factor data['reserved_percentage'] = self.configuration.reserved_percentage data['QoS_support'] = False data['location_info'] = \ 'ZFSVolumeDriver:%s:%s' % (self.hostname, self.zpool) self._stats = data def extend_volume(self, volume, new_size): """Extend an existing voumes size.""" try: self._execute('zfs', 'set', 'volsize=%s' % _sizestr(new_size), '%s/%s' % (self.zpool, volume['name']), run_as_root=True) except putils.ProcessExecutionError as err: LOG.exception(_('Error extending Volume')) LOG.error(_('Cmd :%s') % err.cmd) LOG.error(_('StdOut :%s') % err.stdout) LOG.error(_('StdErr :%s') % err.stderr) raise class ZFSISCSIDriver(ZFSVolumeDriver, driver.ISCSIDriver): """Executes commands relating to ISCSI volumes. We make use of model provider properties as follows: ``provider_location`` if present, contains the iSCSI target information in the same format as an ietadm discovery i.e. '<ip>:<port>,<portal> <target IQN>' ``provider_auth`` if present, contains a space-separated triple: '<auth method> <auth username> <auth password>'. `CHAP` is the only auth_method in use at the moment. """ def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): self.db = kwargs.get('db') self.target_helper = self.get_target_helper(self.db) super(ZFSISCSIDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.backend_name =\ self.configuration.safe_get('volume_backend_name') or 'ZFS_iSCSI' self.protocol = 'iSCSI' def set_execute(self, execute): super(ZFSISCSIDriver, self).set_execute(execute) if self.target_helper is not None: self.target_helper.set_execute(execute) def ensure_export(self, context, volume): volume_name = volume['name'] iscsi_name = "%s%s" % (self.configuration.iscsi_target_prefix, volume_name) volume_path = self.local_path(volume) # NOTE(jdg): For TgtAdm case iscsi_name is the ONLY param we need # should clean this all up at some point in the future model_update = self.target_helper.ensure_export(context, volume, iscsi_name, volume_path) if model_update: self.db.volume_update(context, volume['id'], model_update) def create_export(self, context, volume): """Creates an export for a logical volume.""" volume_path = self.local_path(volume) data = self.target_helper.create_export(context, volume, volume_path) return { 'provider_location': data['location'], 'provider_auth': data['auth'], } def remove_export(self, context, volume): self.target_helper.remove_export(context, volume) def migrate_volume(self, ctxt, volume, host, thin=False, mirror_count=0): """Optimize the migration if the destination is on the same server. If the specified host is another back-end on the same server, and the volume is not attached, we can do the migration locally without going through iSCSI. """ false_ret = (False, None) if volume['status'] != 'available': return false_ret if 'location_info' not in host['capabilities']: return false_ret info = host['capabilities']['location_info'] try: (dest_type, dest_hostname, dest_zpool) = info.split(':') except ValueError: return false_ret if (dest_type != 'ZFSVolumeDriver'): return false_ret if self.hostname != dest_hostname: # TODO(KvdV) Implement zfs send + remote zfs receive combo return false_ret elif dest_zpool != self.zpool: # TODO(KvdV) Implement zfs send + local zfs receive combo return false_ret else: # TODO(KvdV) Perform rename return false_ret def _iscsi_location(self, ip, target, iqn, lun=None): return "%s:%s,%s %s %s" % (ip, self.configuration.iscsi_port, target, iqn, lun) def _iscsi_authentication(self, chap, name, password): return "%s %s %s" % (chap, name, password)

subject: Set the NetApp iSCSI and NFS server ports as configured
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-05-23 19:21:31.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/nfs.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/iscsi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/11614d25772e979d06878d4ac9c7b01c4a39e1dd', 'message': 'Set the NetApp iSCSI and NFS server ports as configured

The NetAppDirectISCSIDriver and NetAppNFSDriver drivers do not set the
netapp_server_port value configured in cinder.conf and only selects a port
based on the transport type (http or https).

This work-around makes netapp_server_port a required configuration
as it overwrites the default port settings implemented in
cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/api.py NaServer.set_transport_type()
and setting netapp_transport_type to https will still use the default
netapp_server_port of 80.

Change-Id: Iee22ef7146adb0f0e6ee8fdd72ec4713a564415b
Closes-Bug: #1322379
'}]
commit_message:
Set the NetApp iSCSI and NFS server ports as configured

The NetAppDirectISCSIDriver and NetAppNFSDriver drivers do not set the
netapp_server_port value configured in cinder.conf and only selects a port
based on the transport type (http or https).

This work-around makes netapp_server_port a required configuration
as it overwrites the default port settings implemented in
cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/api.py NaServer.set_transport_type()
and setting netapp_transport_type to https will still use the default
netapp_server_port of 80.

Change-Id: Iee22ef7146adb0f0e6ee8fdd72ec4713a564415b
Closes-Bug: #1322379
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/56/95256/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fixes cinder quota-defaults information with wrong tenant-id

quota-defaults displays the default information even though specified
tenant-id does not exist.

  cinder quota-defaults wrong_tenant_id

The fix has been applied so that quota-defaults with wrong tenant-id will
display an error with "TenantID not found"

Change-Id: I425112f1bb79bab337e8c3d84214d3dff6756956
Closes-Bug: #1307486

subject: Move cacert property out of "stunnel" and into a new "ssl" group

The CA certificate is currently passed via ssl-source.yaml as
"stunnel.cacert", but this value really has nothing to do with stunnel.

This change proposes that it be exposed as "ssl.ca_certificate",
which is consistent with the overall SSL direction being driven by
os-cloud-config:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/103637/9/os_cloud_config/ssl_pki.py

Because no DIB elements currently rely on this value, the change
should is safe, with no backward compatibility issues.

The CA certificate is currently passed via ssl-source.yaml as
"stunnel.cacert", but this value is not currently used by stunnel
since we have no use case for client cert authentication.

This change proposes that it also be exposed as
"ssl.ca_certificate", which is consistent with the overall SSL
direction being driven by the PKI spec:
  I32473fe797a4c1e28d14c3b82c8892c7c59a4e55

This new CA certificate value will be installed as a trusted CA
on all cloud nodes that issue SSL-secured connection requests to
OpenStack or other infrastructure (MySQL, RabbitMQ) services.

Change-Id: Ibacd7c98980520e11c0df89632013f2ba2dbe370
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-08-12 17:34:20.000000000', 'files': ['ssl-source.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/5d35e97cfa2ac14ac91e2b9038a11e94606c0816', 'message': 'Move cacert property out of "stunnel" and into a new "ssl" group

The CA certificate is currently passed via ssl-source.yaml as
"stunnel.cacert", but this value is not currently used by stunnel
since we have no use case for client cert authentication.

This change proposes that it also be exposed as
"ssl.ca_certificate", which is consistent with the overall SSL
direction being driven by the PKI spec:
  I32473fe797a4c1e28d14c3b82c8892c7c59a4e55

This new CA certificate value will be installed as a trusted CA
on all cloud nodes that issue SSL-secured connection requests to
OpenStack or other infrastructure (MySQL, RabbitMQ) services.

Change-Id: Ibacd7c98980520e11c0df89632013f2ba2dbe370
'}]
commit_message:
Move cacert property out of "stunnel" and into a new "ssl" group

The CA certificate is currently passed via ssl-source.yaml as
"stunnel.cacert", but this value is not currently used by stunnel
since we have no use case for client cert authentication.

This change proposes that it also be exposed as
"ssl.ca_certificate", which is consistent with the overall SSL
direction being driven by the PKI spec:
  I32473fe797a4c1e28d14c3b82c8892c7c59a4e55

This new CA certificate value will be installed as a trusted CA
on all cloud nodes that issue SSL-secured connection requests to
OpenStack or other infrastructure (MySQL, RabbitMQ) services.

Change-Id: Ibacd7c98980520e11c0df89632013f2ba2dbe370
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/21/110121/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fixes cinder quota-update with wrong tenant-id

quota-update returns 200 (OK) even though specified tenant-id
does not exist.

  cinder quota-update wrong-tenant --gigabytes 2

The fix has been applied so that quota-update with wrong tenant-id will
display an error with "TenantID not found"

Change-Id: I892267f9f551d3436faf90a612ac45b04b64c421
Closes-Bug: #1307491

commit_message:
Do not use __builtin__ in python3

__builtin__ does not exist in Python 3, use
six.moves.builtins instead.

Change-Id: I6fbed58f266281f0756b2988d7db08e2792113f3
closes-bug: #1290234

Support volume backup of qcow2 format volume

New feature aims to support volume backup for volumes whose format
is qcow2 other than raw

commit_message:
Use proper exception module

In iscsi, c.brick.exception is imported, but it is only used to
guard database access. Database will never throw
c.brick.exception.NotFound, instead it raises c.exception.NotFound.

This is only half a fix: the true culprit is the confusing duplication
besteen c.exception and c.brick.exception.

Change-Id: I5d345f6f33167bd8be0041860751bdd90361dcf5

commit_message:
Support new format in policy.json in cinder

Merged in the openstack-common policy codes from nova to keep the new
format in policy.json in cinder supported in the same way with that in
nova and other components. The cinder-specific policy and test bits are
also updated for the new format. The policy.json is just changed in the
format.

Change-Id: I92ccab9d8773affacd61c106fdefc1c5dc61bd07
Partial-Bug: #1279263

commit_message:
replace iterator.next() with next(iterator)

According to https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3 iterator.next()
should be replaced with next(iterator).

Change-Id: I97ccde7a028b70892a865ec88165615e201d5117
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/13/98713/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Import fixes from the Nova driver reviews

Import fixes from the Nova driver review, based upon revision 4
of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/111423/

- Add unittests for patcher.create()
- Convert some of the tests for the PXEDriverFields to GenericDriverFields
  and make sure that the delta from the PXE class is covered

Change-Id: Iec8d1d379458b89a2140dc473ad691dc5dd6d3dc

DRBDmanage is a utility for simplified and automated administration
of resources on a multiple-node DRBD 9 cluster.

This POC (currently) only allows create/delete of volumes,

Change-Id: I4b4b859d1abf16098ef51db6afe2bf01255c337b

commit_message:
Proof-of-concept cinder driver for DRBDmanage.

DRBDmanage is a utility for simplified and automated administration
of resources on a multiple-node DRBD 9 cluster.

This POC (currently) only allows create/delete of volumes,
and copying images into them; the next step is snapshot
functionality, so that the Minimum Feature list is available.

Change-Id: I4b4b859d1abf16098ef51db6afe2bf01255c337b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/83/98983/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OVERVIEW ======== This is the library that allows OpenStack/Cinder to use DRBD 9 as a storage backend for creating volumes, using DRBDmanage as an intermediate management layer. Basically, Cinder volume requests get relayed via DBUS to DRBDmanage, which then creates LVs (currently) on the requested number of nodes, defines the DRBD resources, and returns the device node path that OpenStack then passes to KVM. For more details about DRBD, please visit http://www.drbd.org/users-guide-9.0/ch-fundamentals.html For more details about DRBDmanage, please visit http://git.linbit.com/gitweb.cgi?p=drbdmanage.git http://oss.linbit.com/drbdmanage/ http://blogs.linbit.com/p/693/drbdmanage-released/ http://blogs.linbit.com/p/721/drbdmanage-now-easy/ Please note that DRBD9 and DRBDmanage are heavily under development; there are packages available for both, but consider them unsuitable for production use. [ We don't *publish* DRBD9 packages yet, so that people ] [ don't start using it on their production servers. ] [ We have successfully built it on certain kernel ] [ versions, e.g. a build for 2.6.32-431.11.2.el6.x86_64 ] [ is available. ] You will need *at least* DRBDmanage 0.20 (and therefore DRBD 9.0.0pre10 and DRBD-utils 8.9.0rc2) for this driver. DEPENDENCIES INSTALLATION ========================= Please install DRBD9 (kernel module) and a matching user space (8.9.0rc1 or better). DRBDmanage will need to be configured correctly; the VG name in /etc/drbdmanaged-lvm.conf must be set correctly _before_ issuing the "drbdmanage init" command. After connecting the nodes by "drbdmanage add-node" etc. please verify the installation using "drbdmanage nodes"; looking at the output of "drbdsetup status" might be useful for verifying that DRBD9 is talking correctly, too. Please note that the DRBDmanage-Cinder driver currently assumes a minimum redundancy of 2; if you're only using a single node, please configure a fake second one in DRBDmanage by issuing a command like: # drbdmanage add-node fake-node 127.9.9.99 INSTALLATION ============ There are a few small differences, depending on the OpenStack version you use. Eg. with devstack you'll need to move the driver file to /opt/stack/cinder/cinder/volume/drivers/drbdmanagedrv.py, whereas for rdostack the correct path is /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/cinder/volume/drivers/drbdmanagedrv.py First of all, define a new volume type; 'cinder.conf' needs to have [DEFAULT] enabled_backends=drbdmanage [drbdmanage] volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.drbdmanagedrv.DrbdManageDriver Then register the type: # cinder --os-username admin --os-tenant-name admin type-create drbdmanage # cinder --os-username admin --os-tenant-name admin type-key drbdmanage set volume_backend_name=drbdmanage You'll need to allow the cinder-volume service access to DRBDmanage; modify /etc/dbus-1/system.d/org.drbd.drbdmanaged.conf to include the matching user: <policy user="USER"> <allow own="org.drbd.drbdmanaged"/> <allow send_interface="org.drbd.drbdmanaged"/> <allow send_destination="org.drbd.drbdmanaged"/> </policy> USER would be 'stack' for devstack and 'cinder' for rdostack. This should be sufficient to get a "drbdmanage" type in the "Create Volume" UI. VERIFICATION ============ After you've created a volume by "cinder create" or through Horizon, you can review the DRBDmanage data using the commands: # dm resources # dm volumes # dm assignments or, for a low-level view: # drbdsetup status KNOWN PROBLEMS ============== This version is tested only with _exactly_ two nodes; if you only have one, please create a "fake" node in DRBDmanage as described above. Furthermore, this version doesn't support snapshots; only create/delete/attach volume are allowed. This is expected to be fixed in some future version, after design discussions have been done. TROUBLESHOOTING =============== If things go wrong, please look at the cinder-volume output and/or the syslog for error messages. DRBDmanage will log errors as "drbdmanaged". CONTACT ======= Please use drbd-user resp. drbd-dev@lists.linbit.com for discussion.

commit_message:
Set useful vendor/product id in tgt ISCSI exports

This can be very useful for debugging and can be used
to filter out access from tenant volumes within compute
hosts.

Closes-Bug: #1261796

Change-Id: Ib7ddb824043536a92024ada30476d00fd171e800
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/89/62689/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <target %(name)s> backing-store %(path)s vendor_id cinder product_id %(prod_id)s </target> """ <target %(name)s> backing-store %(path)s vendor_id cinder product_id %(prod_id)s %(chap_auth)s </target> """ scsi_prod_id = vol_id[:15] conf_variables = { 'name': name, 'path': path, 'prod_id': scsi_prod_id, 'chap_auth': chap_auth} if chap_auth is None: volume_conf = self.VOLUME_CONF % conf_variables else: volume_conf = self.VOLUME_CONF_WITH_CHAP_AUTH % conf_variables <target %(name)s> driver iser backing-store %(path)s vendor_id cinder product_id %(prod_id)s </target> """ <target %(name)s> driver iser backing-store %(path)s vendor_id cinder product_id %(prod_id)s %(chap_auth)s </target> """

commit_message:
WIP: replace dict.iteritems() with six.iteritems(dict)

According to https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3 dict.iteritems()
should be replaced with six.iteritems(dict).

Change-Id: I72761ead3940dfe6425753981eff41b15fa5c312
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/47/95547/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for (k, v) in six.iteritems(kwargs): for key, value in six.iteritems(visible_admin_meta):
deleted_lines: for (k, v) in kwargs.iteritems(): for key, value in visible_admin_meta.iteritems():

commit_message:
Add create qcow2 support in generic nfs driver

Add a bool "nfs_qcow2_volumes" config to cinder.conf, with it set
to True and "nfs_sparsed_volumes" set to False, volumes will be
created as QCOW2 file rather than regular raw or sparse file.

implements: blueprint qcow2-on-generic-nfs-driver
Change-Id: Ic849babcc78fbe786cb9fc9ab03661c8d9fd4e97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/11/92011/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.BoolOpt('nfs_qcow2_volumes', default=False, help=('Create volumes as QCOW2 files rather than raw files.')), elif getattr(self.configuration, self.driver_prefix + '_qcow2_volumes'): self._create_qcow2_file(volume_path, volume_size)

done in this base class.

commit_message:
Fix markup of section_compute-cells.xml

The markup in the variablelist was inconsistent, some <term> used
<option>, others not. Use <term><option> everywhere.

Change-Id: Idc20b61374341a2cb69474cdacbe8912c358b4a5

commit_message:
Code change for nova support cinder client v2

Use v2 volume endpoint to attach/detach volume would be failed,
due to nova not supporting cinder client v2 yet. This patch is for
nova support cinder client v2.

Implements bp support-cinderclient-v2
Closes-Bug: #1215772
Co-Authored-By: Mike Perez <thingee@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Yaguang Tang <yaguang.tang@canonical.com>

Change-Id: Id8abbbb4d9b0c8c49ab51fc3d958ef0d487467f8

In SSH method of OSTF tests address of controller node is chosen
as the first from list of controller nodes.
It may not work when we have a few controller nodes (HA mode) and one

commit_message:
5.0 Fix for SSH method of OSTF tests

In SSH method of OSTF tests address of controller node is chosen
as the first from list of controller nodes.
It may not work when we have a few controller nodes (HA mode) and one
of controller nodes went away. Now controller node is chosen
from list of controller nodes online.

Change-Id: I7f9eedfc797689e609680016a7085fdf30af24e7

commit_message:
Specification to support external shared network extension for nuage

Change-Id: Ic537aef0a92c0acce269e226965c3ea90fef0279
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/86/105986/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================== External Shared Network Extension for Nuage Plugin ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/external-shared-net-ext-for-nuage-plugin Adding external shared network support to existing nuage networks' Plugin via extension Problem description =================== Besides Floating-IP pool, Nuage's VSP offers functionality of external shared network. While floatingip pool can easily map to external:router type network, there is no matching resource in neutron for external shared network. This effort is to add a plugin extension to support it. Proposed change =============== Add a plugin specific attribute "nuageshared" to network resource. When used in conjunction with external:router=True, it will map to VSP's external shared network. Create only operation will be supported to simplify implementation. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Will need to add following in newly created plugins/nuage/extensions/nuage_network.py:: EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 = { 'networks': { 'nuageshared': { 'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'is_visible': True, 'default': False, 'convert_to': convert_to_boolean} }, } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== There will be code added in create_network method of nuage plugin to pass nuageshared attribute. Based on its value, along with external:shared attribute, it will determine whether to create floating-ip pool or shared network pool. Assignee(s) ----------- Ronak Shah Primary assignee: ronak-malav-shah Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Adding nuageshared as an extended attribute to networks Nuage Unit tests addition Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit Test coverage for extra-route extension within Nuage unit test Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Add min_client_version decorator for CLI tests

This adds the min_client_version decorator to be used in the CLI tests.
The decorator is used skip CLI tests where the command being tested
isn't available in the version of the client we're testing against.

The cmd method is pulled out of the ClientTestBase class so it can be
used by the decorator and is renamed so it does not conflict with the
cmd argument passed to it.

To start using the decorator and show how it works, two known CLI tests
are decorated for minimum version checks on their clients.

Part of blueprint minversion-check-for-cli-tests

Change-Id: I8a0ee390048870d450772fa064d0dc2daa2b7036

commit_message:
Migrate security notes to new repository

The security notes have been migrated to the central security-doc
repository.  This patch cleans out the old contents to prevent
accidental use of this repository for creation of new notes.  This
is a temporary measure until we delete this repository sometime in
the near future.  A pointer to the new repository location has been
added in a README file.

Change-Id: I35b7b0c9c03ba8f416e58d26b9213f9e038357b2

deleted_lines: Title (single sentence) --- ### Summary ### A few sentences describing the issue at a high level. ### Affected Services / Software ### A comma separated list of affected services and OpenStack releases. ### Discussion ### A detailed discussion of the problem. This should have enough detail that the person reading can determine if their deployment is affected, when the problem was introduced, and what types of attacks/problems that an affected deployment would be exposed to. ### Recommended Actions ### A detailed description of what can be done to remediate the problem (if possible). If the recommendation involves configuration changes, example snippets of configuration files should be included here. ### Contacts / References ### This OSSN : <link to OSSN on wiki> Original LaunchPad Bug : <link to launchpad bug for affected project/service> OpenStack Security ML : openstack-security@lists.openstack.org OpenStack Security Group : https://launchpad.net/~openstack-ossg CVE: <CVE number if one was filed>

commit_message:
Convert network/api.py uses of vif database functions to objects

This makes network/api.py use the VirtualInterface object instead of direct
database queries. This is the last direct/obvious use of nova.db.* in the
network api.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects-juno

Change-Id: Ia3eb1694f3708aeceb4c77876a210a7cb6532be1

Add notifications for identity authenticate events

This patch adds support for notifications for when a user authenticates.
For more information on what events keystone supports visit:

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/event_notifications.html#auditing-with-cadf

Change-Id: I73c6971902750b401a29bb21d41617b9775946a0

commit_message:
Convert last use of direct database instance fetching from network api

This is the last db.instance_*() call in network/api.py. This patch
converts it to use the Instance object.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects-juno

Change-Id: Id7897da6daa3d76a95403466be17f9eaef8b7850
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/37/113337/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add a test fixture for translatable strings

Change-Id: I96aec806392672ff69a3af6c3e0a04a621656f78
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.i18n refs/changes/99/113399/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Test fixtures for working with oslo.i18n. """ import fixtures import six from oslo.i18n import _message class Translation(fixtures.Fixture): """Fixture for managing translatable strings. This class provides methods for creating translatable strings using both lazy translation and immediate translation. It can be used to generate the different types of messages returned from oslo.i18n to test code that may need to know about the type to handle them differently (for example, error handling in WSGI apps, or logging). Use this class to generate messages instead of toggling the global lazy flag and using the regular translation factory. """ def __init__(self, domain='test-domain'): """Initialize the fixture. :param domain: The translation domain. This is not expected to coincide with an actual set of message catalogs, but it can. :type domain: str """ self.domain = domain def lazy(self, msg): """Return a lazily translated message. :param msg: Input message string. May optionally include positional or named string interpolation markers. :type msg: str or unicode """ return _message.Message(msg, domain=self.domain) def immediate(self, msg): """Return a string as though it had been translated immediately. :param msg: Input message string. May optionally include positional or named string interpolation markers. :type msg: str or unicode """ return six.text_type(msg)

commit_message:
Add sync_ceph_time method to all Ceph tests

Sometimes after reverting snapshots Ceph health check
alerts about clock skew on some nodes, so an additional
time sync and ceph service restart were added to the
test. Also, refactored methods which are used for ceph
checks.

Change-Id: I6c875f19cd3802e8280de48d121b7900b25a0f3a
Closes-bug: #1349379

commit_message:
Display stack owner when formatting stacks

Stacks are launched by users but scoped to tenants, so users in the same
tenant currently have no way to know owns each stack.  The same is
especially true to unscoped stack lists.  Since humans are much better
with names than they are with numbers, this adds the stack owner
username to the data returned with each stack.

Co-Authored-By: Anderson Mesquita <andersonvom@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint stack-display-fields
Change-Id: Ia1386531025096e0eeaf9e98b478c4453fc8cb01

added_lines: def test_format_stack_username_if_not_tenant_safe(self): self.stack.username = 'foo' info = api.format_stack(self.stack, tenant_safe=False) self.assertEqual('foo', info[rpc_api.STACK_USERNAME]) def test_format_stack_username_not_displayed_if_tenant_safe(self): self.stack.username = 'foo' info = api.format_stack(self.stack, tenant_safe=True) self.assertNotIn(rpc_api.STACK_USERNAME, info) def test_format_stack_username_not_displayed_by_default(self): self.stack.username = 'foo' info = api.format_stack(self.stack) self.assertNotIn(rpc_api.STACK_USERNAME, info)

commit_message:
Fix scss directory imports

If we attempt to import a file with the same name as a directory scss
gets confused and explodes. Make these names unambigious.

Closes-Bug: #1349774

Change-Id: I2d7d384b7ce2d2e073161e17dc10a2653e6ca10e

commit_message:
Add flavors support to mongodb

This patch is a follow-up on the queue's flavor work. It adds support
for such feature to the MongoDB storage driver.

Partially-Implements blueprint: marconi-queue-flavors

Change-Id: Ib3231ab361896e1c08831d17899dd4111710ab9b

commit_message:
Reorganize docs folder

For now, developers guide will be living in doc/source
(this is where all OpenStack projects store their developers docs)
and the user guide will be store in doc/user-guide

Change-Id: Ib539ff40dd9fc4ca413259771e6a19303dd81dd1
